questions.text: A child had recurrent bouts of infections. The diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease was made using the nitroblue tetrazolium test. This test assesses the functions of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The nitroblue tetrazolium test assesses the function of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN).

Nitroblue tetrazolium assay is used as a diagnostic test, particularly for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). It tests the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in neutrophils and monocytes.

Chronic granulomatous disease is a rare X-linked recessive disease. It is characterized by the impaired phagocytic killing of microorganisms by neutrophils and macrophages. Defects in NADPH oxidase lead to defective production of reactive oxygen species after phagocytosis.

These patients have frequent infections by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Burkholderia cepacia complex, Nocardia, Aspergillus, etc. Recurrent folliculitis may prompt early diagnosis of the condition. Following these infections, there is extensive inflammation and suppuration despite antibiotic therapy.

Other features include aphthous ulcers, inflammation of the nares, and granulomas. Granulomas can cause obstruction of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tracts. Autoimmune complications like immune thrombocytopenic purpura and juvenile idiopathic arthritis may also occur.

Management of CGD is mainly treating infections with antibiotics or antifungals depending on the cause. Granulomas are sensitive to steroids and glucocorticoids can be given. 

Other options:

Options B and C: B and T lymphocytes can be assessed by lymphocyte phenotyping. It is useful in the diagnosis of T-cell immunodeficiencies and agammaglobulinemia.

Option D: Complement can be assessed by CH50 and AP50, which are useful in diagnosing complement deficiencies.

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient with increased blood pressure has come to the outpatient department. He asks about lifestyle modifications and a DASH diet was suggested. How much does the systolic blood pressure drop by adopting the DASH diet?

DASH: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension
questions.solution:
The systolic blood pressure drops by 8-14 mmHg by adopting the DASH diet.

DASH is a diet plan which involves consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced fat content. 

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension and the reduction in blood pressure are shown below.

Modification Impact on SBP
Weight reduction to maintain a normal body mass index 5–20 mmHg per 10kg weight loss
DASH diet 8–14 mmHg
Sodium intake reduction (< 6 grams of sodium chloride) 2–8 mmHg
Physical activity: 30 minutes of a brisk walk per day  4–9 mmHg

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Hypertension is a preventable disease. There are two approaches:

  • Primary prevention - includes measures that are taken to reduce the incidence by reducing the risk of onset. Population strategies are dietary modification, weight reduction, and exercise. A high-risk strategy prevents the shooting of blood pressure which might need institutional treatment.
  • Secondary prevention - includes the detection and usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals.

questions.text: What is the period after fertilization during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins?
questions.solution:
The period after fertilization, during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins, is >13 days.

The proposed mechanisms are:

  • Incomplete splitting of one embryo into two 
  • Fusion of a portion of one embryo from a monozygotic pair onto the other.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of air changes in a drawing-room?
questions.solution:
The number of air changes in drawing rooms or living rooms must be 2 – 3 per hour.

The number of air changes in work rooms and assemblies must be 4 – 6 per hour.

questions.text: Which of the following substance is responsible for the feedback inhibition of the rate-limiting enzyme in the hepatic biosynthesis of heme?
questions.solution:
Heme is responsible for the feedback inhibition of the rate-limiting enzyme (i.e. mitochondrial aminolevulinic acid synthase-1 or ALA synthase-1) in the hepatic biosynthesis of the heme.

Heme, probably acting through an aporepressor molecule, acts as a negative regulator of the synthesis of ALAS-1.

ALA synthase-2 is expressed in the erythrocyte precursor cells. It is neither induced by drugs nor feedback regulated by heme.

choices.text: Amphotericin B is the treatment of choice
Causes systemic mycoses in immunocompetent individuals

questions.solution:
The microscopic image shows a typical brush like conidiospores seen in Penicillium species. It causes opportunistic mycoses in immunocompromised individuals.

Microscopic appearance of Penicillium spp.:

  • The hyphae are hyaline and septate.
  • They produce characteristic brush-like conidiophores.
  •  The conidiophore is the stalk-like structure, which bears structures known as metulae from which flask-shaped phialides producing chains of asexual spores known as conidia arise. 

It is a dimorphic fungi.

The treatment usually entails a defined course of Amphotericin B followed by itraconazole.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given image?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows Bennett's fracture. 

Bennett fracture is a fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone which extends into the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. This intra-articular fracture is the most common type of fracture of the thumb and is nearly always accompanied by some degree of subluxation or frank dislocation of the carpometacarpal joint. 

Radiographic features:

  • Two-piece fracture of the 1st metacarpal
  • Intraarticular extension
  • Dorsolateral displacement
  • The lateral pull of the 1st metacarpal shaft by abductor pollicis longus

Barton's fracture:

The dislocation of the radiocarpal joint is the hallmark of Barton's fracture.

The radiographic findings are the following:

  • Comminuted intraarticular fracture of the distal radius
  • Volar rim maintains a relationship with the carpus and both are displaced proximally
  • Fracture of the radial styloid process with loss of radial inclination 

The image below shows Barton's fracture:

A Colles' fracture is a type of fracture of the distal forearm, with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. The following image shows a Colle's fracture 

A Smith's fracture, also sometimes known as a reverse Colles' fracture or Goyrand-Smith's, is a fracture of the distal radius. Here there is a forward displacement of the distal fragment.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of bilateral knee pain. On examination, he had pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles. His X-ray appears as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray image showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, Frenkel's line, and Wimberger's ring sign are suggestive of scurvy.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Clinical features:

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Radiographic features of scurvy include:

  • Wimberger's ring sign - sharp margination of the epiphysis by a sclerotic rim
  • White line of Frankel - calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trumerfeld zone - a lucent zone beneath the Frankel's line due to lack of mineralisation of osteoid
  • Pelkan spurs - due to fractures at the cortical margin
  • Periosteal elevation - due to subperiosteal haemorrhages

 

Other options:

Option A: Rickets occurs due to vitamin D deficiency in children. The patients present with skeletal changes like bowing of legs and bone pain. Radiological features show cupping at metaphysis, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

Option B: Caffey’s disease is infantile cortical hyperostosis. It usually presents at 6 months of age with painful soft tissue swelling and bone thickening. The mandible is the most common bone involved.

Option D: Osteogenesis imperfecta presents with the hallmark features of osteoporosis with increased fragility of bones along with blue sclera, dental fragility as well as hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: The calcium-sensing receptors (CaSR) are located in __________
questions.solution:
The calcium-sensing receptors (CaSR) are located in the parathyroid gland.

The CaSR is a GPCR that couples with Gq and Gi.

Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent that activates the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) and blocks PTH secretion. It is indicated for secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney disease and tumors of the parathyroid gland.

Note: CaSR is also expressed in kidneys.

questions.text: A patient who is planned for cardiac surgery requires central venous pressure (CVP) monitoring. What is the preferred site for central venous cannulation?
questions.solution:
The right internal jugular vein is the most preferred vein for central venous cannulation.

Reasons for preference:   

  • Absence of valves
  • Consistent anatomic location of the internal jugular vein
  • Easily identifiable surface landmarks
  • Direct communication with the right atrium. 

Other sites for central venous cannulation:

  • Subclavian vein: greater risk of pneumothorax
  • Left internal jugular vein: greater risk of pleural effusion & chylothorax
  • Femoral vein: increased risk of thromboembolic complications, infection, and vascular injury.

questions.text: Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis is not treated with _______________
questions.solution:
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis is caused by adenovirus serotypes 3, 7, 8, and 19 and antiviral therapy is not indicated.

The condition is characterised by follicular conjunctivitis associated with preauricular lymphadenopathy. A conjunctival membrane may form in 7-10 days and the cornea could also be involved with punctate epithelial infiltrates and discrete subepithelial opacities.

Treatment is non-specific with lubricants and decongestive drops for relief of discomfort. Antibiotic drops prevent secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: Which of the following patients most likely has Crohn's disease?

choices.text: A 45 year old smoker with colonoscopy showing two skip lesions in terminal ileum and caecum with cobblestone appearance
A 56 year old female with endoscopy showing multiple ulcers in the duodenum and jejunum
A 60 year old male with  colonoscopy showing a continuous lesion of the rectum and distal colon and collar button ulcers
A 23 year old female with pain, diarrhoea and constipation and normal findings on colonoscopy

questions.solution:
Of the given patients, the 45-year-old smoker with colonoscopy showing skip lesions in terminal ileum and caecum, with cobblestone appearance is most likely to have Crohn's disease.

Crohn disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It also has to skip lesions (as in this case: two lesions) and is associated with smoking.

Other options:

Option B: This patient may have Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterised by overproduction of gastrin from a tumour and multiple ulcers in atypical areas. 

Option C: This patient probably has ulcerative colitis, characterized by a continuous lesion with rectal involvement. 

Option D: This patient most likely has irritable bowel syndrome.

questions.text: Where is quarter-staggered arrangement seen?
questions.solution:
The collagen fibers have a triple-stranded, quarter-staggered arrangement. 

In a collagen fibre, tropocollagen molecules are arranged side-by-side. Each fibril is displaced longitudinally from its neighbour by less than one-quarter of its length. This is known as a "quarter-staggered array". This arrangement helps in mineralization.

questions.text: A junior radiologist performing an abdominal ultrasound of a middle aged patient was unable to find the spleen. However, his senior was able to trace some fibrous tissue in its normal location. The patient has no history of trauma or abdominal surgery. Which of the following could be the reason for the absence of the spleen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, the most likely reason is sickle cell anemia.

In patients with sickle cell anemia, the spleen is enlarged in early childhood because of red pulp congestion due to trapping of the sickled RBCs in the splenic cords and sinuses. However, with time, this stasis leads to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and shrinkage of the spleen. By adolescence, only a small fibrous remnant may be left behind in place of the normal spleen. This is known as autosplenectomy. 

The main pathology behind autosplenectomy is microvascular occlusion which occurs in patients with sickle cell anemia. In the parts of the body where the blood flow is sluggish — such as in inflamed areas, or in the cords of the spleen — there is a higher tendency for the sickled RBCs to adhere to the endothelium. This is because sickled red cells express higher amounts of adhesion molecules. Mediators released from granulocytes during an inflammatory process worsen this tendency.

Vascular occlusion due to the adhesion of the sickled RBCs to the vessel wall can cause infarcts in other tissues such as bones, brain and kidney as well. Painful bone crises due to vascular occlusion are common in children and can manifest as hand-foot syndrome (dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet), acute chest syndrome (involves the lung and presents with fever, cough, and chest pain) and priapism.

Thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis both present with splenomegaly and not autosplenectomy.

questions.text: Staging laparotomy was performed in a teenage girl who presented with an adnexal mass. Histopathological examination showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows Schiller-Duval bodies. It is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor).

It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal areas in young children. It is usually unilateral. These tumors are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin.

The image below depicts Schiller-Duval bodies. It consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. 50% of yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in a neonate with intra-uterine growth retardation?
questions.solution:
Anaemia is not seen in IUGR neonates. Instead, polycythemia is seen in them.

Problems of infants with IUGR and pathogenesis:

  • Intrauterine fetal demise: Hypoxia, acidosis, infection, lethal anomaly
  • Perinatal asphyxia: decreased uteroplacental perfusion during labour+chronic fetal hypoxia, meconium aspiration syndrome
  • Hypoglycemia: decreased tissue glycogen stores, decreased gluconeogenesis, hyperinsulinemia, hypothermia, large brain
  • Polycythemia: Fetal hypoxia with increased erythropoietin production
  • Dysmorphology: Syndrome anomalies, Chromosomal genetic disorders, Oligohydramnios induced deformation.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is used to measure intracellular fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Deuterium oxide and inulin are the indicators used for the measurement of intracellular fluid volume (ICF).

The ICF cannot be measured directly. It is calculated by subtracting the extracellular fluid volume (ECF) from the total body water (TBW).

ICF  = TBW - ECF

Indicators used for the measurement of TBW are:

  • Tritium oxide (3H2O)
  • Deuterium oxide (2H2O)
  • Antipyrine

Indicators used for the measurement of ECF are:

  • 22Na
  • 125I-iothalamate
  • Thiosulfate
  • Inulin

Other options:

Option A: Tritium oxide and Evans blue are used for the measurement of TBW and plasma volume respectively.

Option C: Inulin and 125I-albumin are used for the measurement of ECF volume and plasma volume respectively, and together, they are used to calculate the interstitial fluid volume (ECF-plasma volume).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was arrested by the police for disrupting peace in a hotel. He refused to pay his hotel bills saying that he was the prime minister and all services are free for him. When the hotel staff confronted him, he got angry and damaged some hotel property. What are his symptoms suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are suggestive of a delusion of grandeur (megalomania).

Grandiose delusions, delusions of grandeur, or megalomania refer to the exaggerated conception of one's importance, power, or identity. The patient may believe that he is a famous celebrity or has supernatural powers.

A delusion is a false, firm, fixed (unshakable) belief that is not in keeping with the patient’s socio-cultural and educational background.

Delusions are of two types based on their origin:

  • Primary: Delusions that do not occur in response to another psychopathological form such as mood disorder.
  • Secondary: Delusions that are secondary to other morbid psychological conditions like depressive moods and hallucinations. They are understandable when a detailed psychiatric history and examination are available.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with no prior immunization history presents with fever, cough, and coryza. On examination of the buccal mucosa, you see the following. Which stage of the disease is this finding seen in?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Koplik’s spots present in measles. They are seen during the prodromal phase of the illness.  

Koplik's spots are small bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite to the first and second lower molars and are pathognomonic of measles. They contain giant cells, cytoplasmic and intranuclear inclusions, and virion components. They can involve the entire buccal mucosa and fade as the maculopapular rash develops.

The natural history of measles has 3 stages as follows:

  1. Prodromal stage - It consists of cough, coryza, redness of eyes, lacrimation, photophobia, vomiting, and diarrhea. Koplik's spots appear in this stage. 
  2. Eruptive stage - A dusky, red maculopapular rash appears 14 days after onset of infection. It starts behind the ears and spreads downwards to the trunk and lower extremities. Antibodies appear in this stage and are detectable by IgM ELISA. The symptoms such as fever and rash usually resolve spontaneously or go on to develop complications.
  3. Post-measles stage - Weakness and weight loss may persist. The infection may become chronic and cause secondary infections such as cancrum oris, candidiasis etc. 

The image below shows Koplik's spots.

The image below shows the characteristic maculopapular rash in measles

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed for the refractive error given in the image?
questions.solution:
The above image represents the rays of light forming two focal points: both in front of the retina. This type of astigmatism is called compound myopic astigmatism.

Among the above options, -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree is the correct prescription for compound myopic astigmatism (SMA). 

 Prescription in astigmatism: There are 3 components

1) Power of the spherical component: Convex (+) or concave (-) dioptre sphere (DS)

2) Power of the cylinder: Convex (+) or concave (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)

3) Axis (orientation) of the cylinder

For eg: -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree 

In this prescription, -1.00 D concave correction is used in one meridian and -2 D concave correction in the other meridian. which means light rays in both meridians focus at two points in front of the retina.

Other options:

  • +1.00 DS: hypermetropic eye
  • -1.00 DC X 180 degree: there is no sphere (or Plano), i.e., one of the meridians focuses on the retina. -1.00 DC means a concave cylinder is used to focus the myopic rays of the other meridian. And the axis of the cylinder is at 180 degrees. (simple myopic astigmatism)
  • -1.00 DS: myopic eye

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is planned for a prostatectomy by Freyer's approach. Which of the following indicates this approach in the given image?
questions.solution:
The approach marked as "3" depicts Freyer's approach. It is also known as the transvesical approach.

In this approach, the bladder is opened and the prostate is enucleated by putting a finger into the urethra, pushing forward towards the pubes to separate the lateral lobes, and then working the finger between the adenoma and the false capsule. questions.text: Which of the following is the causative agent of water-can perineum?
questions.solution:
Water can perineum is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoea.

The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues, causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses called water can perineum. 

 

In women, the initial infection involves the urethra and cervix uteri. The infection may extend to Bartholin's glands, the endometrium, and the Fallopian tubes, pelvic inflammatory disease, and salpingitis causing sterility. Rarely, peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome).

Chlamydia trachomatis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Ureaplasma urealyticum are the organisms causing non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: Blowback phenomenon is most likely to be seen in ___________

choices.text: Contact wound of the head due to small caliber weapon
Lacerated wound of the head due to a knife with a hilt
Distant shot of the head with a small caliber weapon
Contact wound of the head due to large caliber weapon

questions.solution:
Blowback phenomenon is seen in contact shot and a contact wound of the head from a large caliber weapon is more likely to produce back spatter than a wound of the trunk from a small-caliber weapon.

Gunshot contact wounds and also close range discharges may cause blood and tissue fragments to enter the muzzle, sometimes penetrating for several centimeters, due to negative pressure created following the discharge and is known as back spatter. The presence of back splatter is dependent on both anatomical site that is injured and the weapon used. 

Sometimes blood and tissue may soil the hand or arm of the person firing the gun, a matter of considerable significance in forensic science.

questions.text: The given injury would have most likely occurred due to:
questions.solution:
The image above shows Lichtenberg figures. This type of injury would have most likely occurred due to a lightning strike.

Lichtenberg's figures also called arborescent or filigree burns are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings over the skin that resemble the branches of a tree. They usually appear within minutes to an hour of a lightning injury and are observed as having a fern-like pattern of erythema over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks. 

They occur due to staining of the tissues by hemoglobin released by lysed red blood cells along the path of the lightning strike. They can also appear due to the rupture of smaller blood vessels in several places giving rise to ecchymoses.

Its recognition may be lifesaving in the unaccompanied comatose patient and is important because even delayed resuscitation of lightning victims can be very successful.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with increased hand and foot size, and the facial features depicted in the image. Insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-1) levels are elevated. Which of the following confirms your diagnosis?

GH - Growth Hormone

choices.text: Suppressed growth hormone after oral glucose load
Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load

questions.solution:
The clinical image of a man with mandibular enlargement, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), and jaw malocclusion with elevated IGF-1 suggests the diagnosis of acromegaly. Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load confirms the diagnosis.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

75g of oral glucose load is administered to the patient. The growth hormone levels are measured within 1-2 hours after administration. Normally, GH should be suppressed to less than 0.4 ug/L after the oral glucose load. A failure of suppression of growth hormone confirms the diagnosis of acromegaly. In some patients, growth hormone levels may demonstrate a paradoxical rise. 

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analog), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists or radiation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Elevated random growth hormone levels would not help in diagnosis as GH is secreted in a pulsatile fashion. In addition, the GH level does not correlate with severity. 

Option B - Suppressed growth hormone after an oral glucose load is seen in patients without acromegaly. 

Option D - Elevated random prolactin levels are seen in 25% of patients with acromegaly but is not used to confirm the diagnosis. 

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.solution:

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

    • Aortic aneurysm

    • Patent ductus arteriosus with right to left shunt

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be removed by dialysis?
questions.solution:
Verapamil cannot be removed by dialysis.

Verapamil has a high volume of distribution and not mainly restricted to the vascular compartment. Therefore, It cannot be removed by dialysis during an overdose.

Dialysis is effective in removing the drugs if they are sufficiently present in the free form in the plasma.

Drugs not suitable for dialysis:

  • Those having a very high volume of distribution, like digoxin, verapamil, and organophosphates.
  • Those having a high level of plasma protein binding, like diazepam

questions.text: A 6-year-old with HIV is brought with complaints of the rash shown below. Where does DNA replication occur in the viruses falling in the same family as the microbe causing this rash?
questions.solution:
The image shows pink, fleshy umbilicated papules suggesting molluscum contagiosum. It is caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus belonging to Poxviridae. DNA replication in these viruses occurs in the host cytoplasm.

Replication of DNA in DNA viruses typically occurs in the host nucleus. However, poxviruses are the exception - replication of DNA occurs in the host cytoplasm. Replication of RNA in RNA viruses typically occurs in the host cytoplasm. However, orthomyxoviruses and retroviruses are the exception - replication of RNA occurs in the host nucleus.

questions.text: A peripheral smear of a 40-year-old female with chronic anaemia and gall stones is as seen below. The patient develops a sudden worsening of anaemia requiring transfusion. What is the most likely Etiology?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows many spherocytes classically described in hereditary spherocytosis.

  • The generally stable clinical course of hereditary spherocytosis is sometimes punctuated by an aplastic crisis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection.
  • Parvovirus infects and kills red cell progenitors, effectively causing red cell production to cease until an immune response commences, generally in 1 to 2 weeks.
  • The reduced life span of HS red cells + cessation of erythropoiesis → leads to a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Transfusions may be necessary to support the patient until the immune response clears the infection

Investigation Value

Serum pH 7.1
Serum anion gap 11
Urinary pH 6.4
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 RTA. In this condition, calcium phosphate and oxalate stones are formed in the distal convoluting tubules (DCT).

In this condition, there is a defect in H+ secretion by the distal tubules. This leads to:

  • Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
  • Urinary pH > 5.5

    • Impaired H+ secretion causes K+ wasting

Acidemia leads to hypercalcemia and then hypercalciuria. There is also hypocitraturia as acidemia induces increased cell citrate utilization. Normally, citrate in the urine binds to calcium and increases its solubility. In the absence of citrate in the urine, calcium begins to precipitate. This leads to nephrocalcinosis and calcium phosphate and oxalate stones.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male from West Bengal presents with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is given in the image. Which of the following is the method of choice for the diagnosis of the disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. The rapid dipstick test has become the mainstay in the serological diagnosis of Kala Azar and is the method of choice for the diagnosis of the disease.  

The image shows amastigotes located intracellularly in macrophages.

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sandflies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.  

It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.  

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of VL. Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear is also confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody est.
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: This test is based on the skin reaction. Induration of 5 mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from non-immune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted with complaints of fever, anorexia, vomiting, abdominal pain and dark urine since 6 days. On investigation, he had elevated liver enzymes and serology was positive for IgM hepatitis A antibodies. Which of the following liver enzymes is most specific for his condition?
questions.solution:
The enzyme most specific for his condition, acute viral hepatitis, is alanine aminotransferase (ALT).

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is predominantly found in the liver and therefore is a more specific marker for hepatocellular damage than AST.

Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) is found in various tissues. The AST/ALT ratio is very important.

  • AST/ALT <1 is seen in hepatocellular damage like in NAFLD, toxic hepatitis, paracetamol toxicity. In cirrhosis, the ratio becomes more than 1.
  • AST/ALT> 2 is suggestive while AST/ALT> 3 is highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Alkaline phosphatase rise is seen in many liver diseases but more than fourfold rise indicates cholestasis.

Option D: GGT is used to identify occult alcohol use.

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the aortic valve will open at point ________.
questions.solution:
The aortic valve will open at point 3.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Pressure-volume diagram during the cardiac cycle:

The pressure-volume diagram plots the changes in the pressure and volume in the left ventricle that occur during the cardiac cycle. The X-axis shows the changes in ventricular volume, while the Y-axis shows the changes in ventricular pressure.

 

It has the following phases.

Phase I- This phase is called the period of filling and extends between points A and B. Point A is at the end of systole when the ventricular volume is about 50 mL. This volume is called end-systolic volume. The pressure at this point is about 2 to 3 mmHg. The volume and pressure go on increasing as the blood from the atrium flows to the ventricle during diastole. At the end of diastole, marked by point B, the ventricle will have a volume of around 120 mL. This volume is called end-diastolic volume. The pressure is slightly raised to 5-7 mmHg. 

Phase II- It is the phase of isovolumetric contraction, and extends between points B and C. At the end of diastole (point B), a slight increase in the ventricular pressure closes the mitral valve, and contraction starts. The ventricle contracts while both mitral and aortic valves are closed. Therefore, the pressure within the ventricle slowly rises without any changes in the volume. 

Phase III- It is the phase of ejection and extends between point C and point D. Point C is the place where the aortic valve opens. The pressure within the left ventricle rises slowly during isovolumetric contraction until it is sufficient to open the aortic valve. Once the aortic valve opens, blood within the left ventricle is ejected into the aorta. This decreases the volume of the left ventricle, while increasing the pressure within the ventricle.

Phase IV- It is the period of isovolumetric relaxation. It extends between points D and A. At the end of the ejection (Point D), the aortic valve closes. However, the ventricular relaxation continues despite closed aortic and mitral valves. Therefore, the ventricular pressure continues to fall while the volume remains the same. The ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 mL of blood left in the ventricle and pressure of about 2 to 3 mmHg.

End-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR)

ESPVR is the maximum pressure that can be developed by the ventricle at the end-systolic volume. It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops. This line can be extended down to the x-axis. The slope of this line is called as ESPVR slope.

questions.text: Which of the following patients will be classified as stage III (B) according to Ann Arbor staging for Hodgkin lymphoma?

choices.text: A 25 year old male patient who has fever, night sweats and lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla
A 25 year old male patient who has lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions without symptoms
A 25 year old male patient who has fever and lymph nodes in the cervical region and axilla
A 25 year old male patient who has lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla without symptoms

questions.solution:
A 25-year-old male who has a fever and lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla will be classified as stage III (B). Involvement of lymph nodes on both sides of the diaphragm with fever (or night sweats/unexplained weight loss >10%) is stage III (B) of Ann-Arbor staging.

Other Options:

Option B: A 25-year-old male patient who has lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions without symptoms will be classified as II (A).

Option C: A 25-year-old male patient who has a fever and lymph nodes in the cervical region and axilla will be classified as II (B).

Option D: A 25-year-old male patient who has lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla without symptoms will be classified as III (A).

questions.text: A child from Bihar has a fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia. The organism shown below is found to be the causative vector of the underlying condition. Identify the vector.
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history and the image given in the question, the child is suffering from Kala-azar and the vector for kala-azar is the phlebotomine sandfly. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is an arthropod-borne protozoal infection. The causative vector is the female phlebotomine sandfly, Phlebotomus argentipes. Cutaneous leishmaniasis occurs due to the bite of P. papatasi and P. sergenti. Clinical features of visceral leishmaniasis include anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and fever. In cutaneous leishmaniasis, painful ulcers at the site of sandfly bite may be present. Ulcers around the margins of the mouth and nose may be present in the mucocutaneous variety. 

Preventive measures include the usage of residual insecticides such as DDT (resistant to P. papatasi in North Bihar) in endemic areas. Spraying of insecticides should be done up to a height of 6 feet and at the rate of 1-2 g per sq. meter. Personal protective measures such as the usage of repellent creams and protective nets should be encouraged. Sanitation is also important by eliminating breeding sites such as leftover organic matter, broken mud pots, burrows, and rubbish around the house. 

Other diseases transmitted by phlebotomus include oriental sore and sandfly fever.

Other options:

Option A: Culex mosquitoes are the vector for filariasis.

Option C: Anopheles mosquitoes are the vector for malaria.

Option D: Soft tick is the vector in diseases such as Q fever and relapsing fever. It is shown below.

  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen

questions.text: Identify the marked ECG feature in a patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia.
questions.solution:
The ECG feature of ventricular tachycardia seen in the given image is a fusion beat. It occurs when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex.

Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is defined as ≥ 3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions at a rate of >100/min. It is characterized by:

  • Wide QRS complex
  • AV dissociation- Atrial activity independent of ventricular activity, seen on the ECG as every p wave not followed by QRS complex
  • Fusion beats- occur when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex
  • Capture beats occur when the SA node transiently ‘captures’ the ventricles, that is, ventricles are depolarized by the impulses from the SA node producing a QRS complex of normal duration.

The given ECG shows a fusion beat (red arrow), and a capture beat (green arrow) can also be seen:

 

The given image shows capture beats in VT:

 

Option C: Polymorphic QRS, that is, continuously changing QRS morphology is seen in polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Option D: Triphasic QRS (eg. RSR′ pattern on V1) is seen in supraventricular tachycardias with the wide QRS complex.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase that causes an accumulation of cAMP, leading to an outpouring of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the small intestinal lumen, and the consequent watery diarrhea in cholera?

choices.text: A2 fragment of A subunit of enterotoxin
A1 fragment of A subunit of enterotoxin

questions.solution:
A1 fragment of A subunit of enterotoxin causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes 

The consequent watery diarrhoea is isotonic with plasma but contains much more of potassium and bicarbonate.

Mechanism of action of cholera toxin:

  • The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit, on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit.
  • A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes and the consequent watery diarrhea, that is isotonic with plasma but contains much more of potassium and bicarbonate.
  • The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.
  • All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

Cholera vibrios also possess the lipopolysaccharide O antigen (LPS, endotoxin), as in Gram-negative intestinal bacilli. This apparently plays no role in the pathogenesis of cholera but is responsible for the immunity induced by killed vaccines.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presented with neurological symptoms like seizures, focal neurological deficits, and diplopia. There is history of headache, nausea, dizziness, irritability, and a low-grade fever for the past 3 months. Brain biopsy showed granulomatous inflammation, trophozoites, and cysts. The trophozoites were large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia. Which of the following organisms is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granulomatous amebic encephalitis. It is caused by acanthamoeba.

Granulomatous amebic encephalitis: It is a granulomatous infection of the brain and spinal cord that typically occurs in persons with a compromised immune system. 

  • Granulomatous amebic encephalitis is believed to follow the inhalation of the dried cysts. The incubation period is long and the evolution of the illness is slow. 
  • The clinical picture is that of intracranial space-occupying lesions with seizures, pareses and mental deterioration.
  • Diagnosis of GAE is made by demonstration of trophozoites (The trophozoites are large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized
    by spine-like pseudopodia)     and cysts in brain biopsy, culture and immunofluorescence microscopy using monoclonal antibodies.

Other options:

Naegleria fowleri a pathogenic free-living amoeba which causes the disease primary amoebic meningoencephalitis(PAM)

Naegleria fowleri:

  • Patients are mostly previously healthy young adults or children, the infection comes from water containing free-living amoeba and usually follows swimming or diving in ponds.
  • The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis (PAM).
  • The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.
  • In the incubation period, the patient experiences anosmia, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck, ataxia, seizure and coma and ends fatally within a Week. (average 5 days). 

Toxoplasma: Trophozoites are crescent-shaped and are 3-7 μm in size.

Plasmodium falciparum: Runs more acute course. In peripheral blood smear, ring forms and gametocytes are seen.

questions.text: A  G2P1 woman presents to the clinic at 36 weeks of gestation. Her husband had recently visited China and now they have both tested positive for COVID 19. She has no other medical problems complicating her pregnancy. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: C-section is the preferred mode of delivery
Vigorous IV fluid therapy recommended during labour
Aim to keep oxygen saturation more than 94% during labour

questions.solution:
Aim to keep oxygen saturation above 94% in this patient.

In case of a COVID 19 confirmed case, maternal observations and assessment during labour should be continued as per standard practice, with the addition of hourly oxygen saturation. Aim to keep oxygen saturation more than 94%, titrating oxygen therapy accordingly.

Other options:

  • There is currently no evidence to favour one mode of birth over another. Mode of birth should not be influenced by the presence of COVID-19, unless the woman’s respiratory condition demands urgent intervention for birth.  

  • There is no evidence that epidural or spinal analgesia or anaesthesia is contraindicated in the presence of coronaviruses. Epidural analgesia is recommended in labour, to women with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 to minimise the need for general anaesthesia if urgent intervention for birth is needed.

  • Apply caution with IV fluid management. Given the association of COVID-19 with acute respiratory distress syndrome, women with moderate to severe symptoms of COVID-19 should be monitored using hourly fluid input/output charts. Efforts should be targeted towards achieving neutral fluid balance in labour, in order to avoid the risk of fluid overload.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of loose stools. On history taking, he reveals to have consumed food from a bakery 3 hours back. Which of the following is wrong about the toxin involved?
questions.solution:

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hours after consuming contaminated food (other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hours is Bacillus cereus-Emetic strains).

  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.
  • Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient.

Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO.

Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient who is a known case of diabetes mellitus with an HbA1c value of 8.8% has been posted for surgery after pre-anesthetic evaluation. Which of the following is used for the physical status classification of the patient during the pre-anesthetic evaluation?

American Society of Anesthesiologists - ASA
questions.solution:
The American Society of Anesthesiologists classification (ASA-PS) is used to classify physical status.

An integral part of the pre-anesthetic evaluation is assessing a patient's risk for undergoing anesthesia and surgery. This helps the anesthetist make informed clinical decisions and helps the patient understand their risks. 

After classifying patients based on this risk assessment, those who require more intensive postoperative monitoring can be identified. In addition, patients who are at high risk for complications can be identified and alternative interventions considered. 

The ASA-PS is the most commonly used risk assessment. However, it is important to note that it describes only the patient's preoperative status and not the risks associated with the specific procedure that the patient will undergo. 

Thyromental distance (Option A), Mallampati classification (Option B), and neck circumference (Option D) are used to assess difficult airways. 

 

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes  

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of double vision. On examination, it is noticed that the patient’s right eye is capable of abduction but not adduction. There is horizontal nystagmus in the right eye. The left eye however is not capable of either abduction or adduction. Where would you expect the brain lesion to be present?
questions.solution:
The given description is that of One and a half syndrome. Left PPRF and Left MLF lesion are both involved in this condition.


The pathologic lesion is in the left dorsal pontine tegmentum which involves both ipsilateral PPRF (or the abducens nucleus) and the ipsilateral Median longitudinal fasciculus. This causes the paralysis of abduction and adduction on the left side, and only paralysis of adduction on the right.

Horizontal gaze

  • It involves 2 muscles: ipsilateral lateral rectus and contralateral medial rectus.
  • The center for this pathway is parapontine reticular formation (PPRF).
  • From here, they move to the ipsilateral 6th nerve nucleus.
  • Next, they pass through the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus.

In the left One and a half syndrome, Due to the PPRF lesion, the horizontal gaze of the left eye is lost (Left lateral rectus and right medial rectus). Left medial rectus adduction is lost due to the lesion in left MLF and there is abduction nystagmus in the right eye.

 

Image: The Horizontal gaze pathway

Lesions in this pathway

  • Horizontal gaze palsy: Due to lesion in the PPRF of the same side
  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO): Caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
  • One and a half syndrome: Caused by lesions in both MLF and PPRF of the same side.

Vertical gaze palsy

Center is located in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the dorsal midbrain (riMLF).

The important types of vertical gaze palsy are as follows:

  • Parinaud's syndrome: Upgaze palsy
  • Steel–Richardsons syndrome: Downgaze palsy

  • Muscular branches
  • Profunda femoris artery
  • Descending genicular artery

questions.text: Which of the following is an ultra-short acting anaesthetic agent used for a short painful procedure?
questions.solution:
The ultra-short acting anaesthetic agent for a short painful procedure is remifentanil. Analgesic action (peak) is achieved within 1 to 1.5 min following intravenous administration.

The rapid onset of action and the rapid recovery (within 15 min) owing to metabolism by plasma esterases of remifentanil make it an ideal analgesic for short painful procedures. The elimination is independent of hepatic metabolism or renal excretion. Remifentanil is not used intraspinally because of formation of glycine which is a inhibitory neurotransmitter.

Other options: 

Option A : Sufentanil has rapid onset of action within 5 min. It is given intravenous or epidural route. Sufentanil and fentanyl are used in post operative or labour analegia.

Option C : Analgesic effects of meperidine is achieved in about 15 min after oral administration. It is effective in post anesthetic shivering. It is not used for longer duration due to accumulation of seizure-inducing metabolite (normeperidine) . It also causes histamine release. 

Option D : Fentanyl has rapid onset of action within 5 mins same as sufentanil and has short duration of action. But remifentanil is ultra short acting.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 55-year old man who was diagnosed with sepsis. Identify the pattern of breathing.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Kussmaul’s Breathing. It is a type of deep, rapid breathing usually implies metabolic acidosis, but can also occur with Ponto-mesencephalic lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament. There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins, which include intermediate filaments, microfilaments, and microtubules.

Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not actively reorganize like actin and microtubules. They impart tensile strength and allow cells to bear mechanical stress. They are:

  • Lamin A, B, and C
  • Vimentin
  • Desmin
  • Neurofilament
  • Glial fibrillary acidic protein
  • Cytokeratins

Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin.  The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

Clinical significance: Each intermediate filament is a tumor marker for well-differentiated tumors, arising from the corresponding site of distribution.

Other option:

Laminins are high molecular weight proteins of the extracellular matrix. They form the major component of the basal lamina.

questions.text: Which is the best specimen for cyanide poisoning?
questions.solution:
The spleen is the best specimen for cyanide poisoning. It has the highest concentration of the poison owing to its presence of RBCs.

In deaths due to poisoning from HCN, rigor mortis sets in early and persists longer. 

  • In the case of suspected cyanide poisoning, the cranial cavity should be opened first as the odor of bitter almonds is well marked in the brain tissue.
  • The basal ganglia are particularly sensitive to cyanide toxicity. Basal ganglia injury may be due to either direct cellular injury or secondary to hypoxic effects.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female patient presents with petechiae and one episode of epistaxis. She gives a history of an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. Her lab reports are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000 cells/μL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing petechiae and one episode of epistaxis following upper respiratory tract infection, and lab reports showing a platelet count of 12,000/μL are suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Since this patient has had only one episode of epistaxis and her hemoglobin is normal, the most appropriate management for this patient would be prednisolone.

In patients without significant bleeding and without severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 5000 cells/μL), the initial treatment is with glucocorticoids such as prednisolone or dexamethasone.

If the patient has severe bleeding or severe thrombocytopenia, IVIg and glucocorticoids are used in conjunction. Anti-D is used as an alternative to IVIg, but is not preferred because of the risk of severe hemolytic reactions. Platelet transfusions (option B) are reserved for patients in whom there is a need to immediately raise the platelet counts. 

The decision to start treatment in a patient who is incidentally diagnosed and doesn't have any bleeding manifestations is based on the platelet count. Treatment is usually started for these patients if the platelet count is < 30,000 cells/μL.

Splenectomy (option C) has been used previously for patients who relapse after glucocorticoid therapy, but is now a reserved treatment option. In most adult patients, ITP resolves spontaneously, and so it is reasonable to observe the patient with intermittent treatment with IVIg before surgery is considered.

questions.text: The intravenous anesthetic agent showing emergence reactions belong to which class of compounds _______
questions.solution:
Phencyclidines, like ketamine, show emergence reactions. Ketamine is an arylcyclohexylamine, a congener of phencyclidine.

Emergence reactions seen with ketamine include vivid dreaming, extracorporeal experiences (sense of floating out of the body), and illusions (misinterpretation of a real, external sensory experience) during emergence from anesthesia. These are usually associated with excitement, confusion, euphoria, and fear.

Ketamine acts at multiple receptors, including the NMDARs, opioid receptors, and monoaminergic receptors and produces dissociative anesthesia.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient was diagnosed with rectal prolapse. The operating surgeon decided to perform surgery by an abdominal approach. Which of the following procedures can be done through this approach?
  1. Delorme's operation
  2. Suture rectopexy
  3. Altemeier rectosigmoidectomy
  4. Resection rectopexy
  5. Thiersch's encirclement
questions.solution:
Suture rectopexy and resection rectopexy are performed by the abdominal approach while Delorme's operation, Altemeier rectosigmoidectomy, and Thiersch's encirclement are done through the perineal approach for rectal prolapse.

Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Rectal prolapse is of two types:

1) Partial rectal prolapse- in this type, only the mucosal layer of the rectum is prolapsed. It is seen in children. The first episode is managed by digital reposition. If there is a recurrence, then Theirsch's wiring or sclerotherapy is done. 

2) Complete rectal prolapse- in this type, all the layers of the rectum are prolapsed. It is seen in adults due to the weakening of the pelvic floor. It is managed by using the following approaches:

  • The perineal approach- it is easy to perform, has fewer complications but a high recurrence rate. It is preferred in elderly patients with comorbidities. The surgeries done using this approach for rectal prolapse are the following:
    • Thiersch's wiring- a steel wire/silastic/nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defaecation. This procedure is rarely used now.
    • Delorme's mucosectomy- in this procedure, the rectal mucosa is stripped circumferentially from the rectum over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures. The excess rectal mucosa is excised and a mucosal anastomosis is performed.
    • Altemeier's rectosigmoidoscopy- in this procedure, the rectum is prolapsed through the anal canal and a full-thickness resection is performed, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. This is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. 

  • The abdominal approach- it is difficult to perform, has more complications but a lower recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach are the following: 
    • Ripstein's procedure- it involves the placement of a prosthetic mesh around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory.
    • Well's procedure- it involves posterior rectopexy. 
    • Suture rectopexy
    • Mesh rectopexy
    • Lateral (Orr-Loygue)
    • Ventral
    • Resection rectopexy (Frykman–Goldberg)

The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position. Abdominal approaches (laparoscopic, robotic, or open) are preferred for younger patients, particularly those with constipation or associated pelvic floor disorders.

questions.text: Arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals the following values: pH of 7.1 and HCO3- of 6 mEq/L. Assuming this is a case of metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis, what is the expected pCO2?
questions.solution:
The expected pCO2 value will be 17 mm Hg.

The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis, plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L - signifies metabolic acidosis. 

The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula: Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2.

Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19. 

Alternatively,

The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.25 mm Hg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.

The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L

Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.25 = 22.5

Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22.5 = 17.5 mmHg (roughly ~ 17 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)

This method is also used to assess compensation. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old-man with pulmonary tuberculosis comes to the hospital with complaints of foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Otoscopy reveals multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane. Histopathology demonstrates submucous tubercles in the middle ear cleft. Which of the following is the most common complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patients clinical features are suggestive of tuberculous otitis media. The most common complication is facial nerve palsy.

Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It presents as painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in middle ear cleft are seen.

Pathology: Submucosal tubercles in middle ear cleft, necrosis of tympanic membrane

Complications: Facial nerve palsy (most common), Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis.

Treatment: ATT, aural toilet, treatment of secondary infection, mastoid surgery for complications.

questions.text: Which is the first region to show changes in rigor mortis?
questions.solution:
The rigor mortis changes begins in the left chamber of the heart. 

Rigor mortis/cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening refers to stiffening and shortening of muscles following death.

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in the order. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

The order of appearance of rigor mortis:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

questions.solution:
Yuzpe method of emergency contraception are combination oral contraceptive containing regimen, i.e Ethinyl estradiol 0.05 mg + norgestrel 0.5 mg 2 tablets. It should be taken within 72 hours of intercourse.

Hormonal contraceptives have different mechanisms of action depending on which day of the menstrual cycle intercourse occurs and which day the tablets are given.

One major mode is inhibition or delay of ovulation. Other suggested mechanisms include

  • endometrial changes that prevent implantation,
  • interference with sperm transport or penetration, and
  • impaired corpus luteum function.

 

Emergency hormonal contraception is not a form of medical abortion. Rather, this method prevents ovulation or implantation. It cannot disrupt a zygote that has implanted.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who is on regular dialysis is planned for an open cholecystectomy. What is the ideal muscle relaxant of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium is the muscle relaxant of choice for the patient with renal and hepatic impairment.

Atracurium undergoes Hoffman’s elimination. It is the non-enzymatic non-organ dependent spontaneous degradation. Atracurium is metabolized 95% by Hoffman's elimination and 5% by ester hydrolysis. 

Cisatracurium also undergoes Hoffman’s elimination.

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.solution:
The given image shows a chemo port. It is totally implantable venous access devices used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Internal jugular veins and subclavian veins are the commonly used venous access for port placement. These devices are usually retained over a period of 1 to 2 years or more after which the device is explanted.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important photochemical reaction involved in phototherapy?
questions.solution:
Isomerization is the most important photochemical reaction involved in Phototherapy.

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by these mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state. 
  • Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation.    

The most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia ranges from 460–490 nm (Blue-green light).

questions.text: Forchheimer spots are seen in ______
questions.solution:
Forchheimer spots are seen in Rubella (aka German Measles). They are tiny rose-coloured lesions in the oropharynx or petechial haemorrhages on the soft palate.

In children, the first manifestation of rubella is usually the rash. It begins on the face and neck as small irregular pink macules that coalesce. About the time of onset of rash examination of oropharynx reveals Forschheimer spots.

 

Koplik spots are a pathognomonic sign of measles.

 

Forchheimer spots:

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: In a patient with interstitial lung disease, which of the following parameters of pulmonary function test would be normal?
questions.solution:
Interstitial lung disease is a restrictive lung disease. Therefore, the FEV1/FVC ratio would be normal on the pulmonary function test.

Interstitial lung disease increases the recoil tendency of the lung. This lowers the total lung capacity (TLC), functional residual capacity (FRC) as well as forced vital capacity (FVC). Maximal expiratory flows such as FEV1 are also decreased. Moreover, the destruction of the pulmonary capillaries by the fibrotic processes results in a marked reduction in the diffusion capacity. Oxygenation is severely reduced because of persistent perfusion of alveolar units which are underventilated due to pulmonary fibrosis.
