questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Rosenbach sign - Pulsations of the liver
Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen
Muller sign - Systolic pulsations of uvula

questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen. Traube's sign is a pistol shot sound heard over femoral arteries. 

Aortic regurgitation (AR). 

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other signs :

  • Pulsations of the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly are called Gerhardt’s sign. (Option B)
  • Rosenbach sign is seen in AR where pulsations are felt over the liver (Option A)
  • Becker's sign is the presence of retinal artery pulsation on fundoscopy. (Option C)
  • Systolic pulsations of uvula is known as Muller's sign. (Option D)

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

  • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
  • In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:
    • The patient is symptomatic
    • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
    • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

questions.text: All of the following are true about trigeminal neuralgia except ?

choices.text: No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.solution:
Trigeminal neuralgia is associated with superficial pain.

Trigeminal neuralgia:

  • More common in females over 50 years
  • Characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory
  • Bilateral or early onset is associated with multiple sclerosis
  • Unilateral trigeminal nerve compresion can be due to superior cerebellar artey.
  • Pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief.
  • Triggered by touch, a cold wind or eating.
  • Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux).
  • No objective signs of sensory loss.
  • Drug of choice-carbamazepine

questions.text:
A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she came back with fever, tachycardia, and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. 
Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Oral contraceptive is a risk factor
MR venogram is used for diagnosis
Empty delta sign may be seen on CECT head

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of seizures and headache in puerperium points to a diagnosis of cortical venous thrombosis, where the lateral or superior sagittal venous sinuses are usually involved.

Cortical vein thrombosis :     

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pro-thrombotic conditions (inherited thrombophilias, APLA syndrome)

Clinical presentation

  • Highly variable
  • Headache is the most common symptom.
  • With or without
    • Vomiting
    • Papilledema
    • Focal deficits

Investigation

  • Brain MRI with MR venography – most sensitive
  • CT – normal in 30% of cases.
  • CECT may show empty delta sign in superior sagittal sinus thrombosis.

questions.solution:
Premature menopause is menopause occurring before 40 years.

The average age of menopause is 47 years and the range is between 45 to 50 years.

questions.text: You have four patients in the medicine ward who complain of breathlessness. Based on Well's score, which of the following patients is at low risk for pulmonary embolism?

choices.text: A 75 year old woman who underwent total hip replacement 2 days ago and now has leg pain, swelling and tachycardia
A 65 year old man with a history of thyroid carcinoma who had surgery 2 months ago only and currently has stable vitals
A 60 year old woman who underwent laparotomy and has been immobile for 3 days with a heart rate of 110 beats/min
A 70 year old man with a prior history of deep vein thrombosis who presents with haemoptysis, leg pain, swelling and tachycardia

questions.solution:
A 65-year-old man with a history of thyroid carcinoma who had surgery 2 months ago only and currently has stable vitals has a low risk of developing a pulmonary embolism based on Well's criteria (Score of <2). This patient, who doesn't have any symptoms of DVT and has stable vitals has a Well's score or 1, which puts him at low risk. 

Other Options:

Option A: A 75-year-old woman who recently underwent a total hip replacement and now has leg pain, swelling, and tachycardia has a Well's score of >6, which puts her at high risk for pulmonary embolism.

Option C: A 60-year-old woman who underwent laparotomy and has been immobile for 3 days with a heart rate of 110 beats/min has a Well's score of 3, which puts her at moderate risk for pulmonary embolism.

Option D: A 70-year-old man with a prior history of deep vein thrombosis who presents with haemoptysis, leg pain, and swelling has a Well's score of >6, putting him at high risk for pulmonary embolism.

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include:

  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

choices.text: A 28-year-old man with successful repair of a cyanotic congenital heart defect 26 years ago, undergoing tooth extraction
A 30-year-old woman with a prosthetic aortic valve, undergoing replantation of the avulsed teeth

A 23-year-old man with no history of cardiovascular disease undergoing routine dental cleaning

questions.solution:
A prosthetic heart valve is one of the indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing dental procedures.

The American Heart Association and European Cardiac Society have recommended antibiotic prophylaxis for patients undergoing invasive dental procedures that involve the manipulation of gingival tissue or periapical region or perforation of the oral mucosa when performed on patients with high-risk cardiac lesions.

Some invasive dental procedures:

  • Tooth extraction
  • Periodontal surgery, subgingival scaling, and root planing
  • Replantation of avulsed teeth
  • Other surgical procedures such as implant placement or apicoectomy

High-risk cardiac lesions:

  • Prosthetic heart valves or prosthetic material used for valve repair    
  • History of endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits.
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the first 6 months after repair.
  • Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual shunt or valvular regurgitation
  • Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement.
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation (recommended only by the American Heart Association)

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for patients undergoing gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures; however, if there is a genitourinary tract infection, the infection is to be treated prior to the procedure.

Other options:

Option A: Antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated if the invasive dental procedure is done only within 6 months of complete repair. As the patient has undergone successful repair of the defect 26 years ago, antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed.

Option C: Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required for a screening colonoscopy (gastrointestinal procedure).

Option D: Dental cleaning does not routinely need antibiotic prophylaxis in patients without a history of cardiac disease.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter that the obstetrician is measuring in the image below is _______.
questions.solution:
The AP diameter that the obstetrician is measuring is the diagonal conjugate.

Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet:

  • Diagonal conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. 
    • It measures 12 cm (4 ¾").
  • Obstetric conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis.
    • It measures 10 cm (4").
  • Anatomical/true conjugate/conjugate vera:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. 
    • It measures 11 cm.

The clinically diagonal conjugate is measured, and the obstetric conjugate is derived by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with respect to a solitary bone cyst?

choices.text: They are asymptomatic unless complicated by pathological fracture
Trapdoor sign can be seen on X-ray
They commonly occur in the diaphysis of the bone

questions.solution:
A solitary bone cyst (unicameral bone cyst/ simple bone cyst) most commonly occurs in the metaphysis of the bone.

Simple bone cyst always occurs during the first two decades of life, most often between 4-10 years of age with a 2:1 male preponderance. It is a benign unilocular cyst filled with straw coloured serosanguinous fluid.

The commonest site is the proximal humerus. They are usually asymptomatic, but pathological fractures may occur through the cyst wall and may cause pain and swelling. The cyst may cause growth disturbances due to its proximity to the growth plate.

On X-ray, a bone fracture fragment may be seen resting in a dependent portion of the cyst. This is known as the fallen fragment/fallen leaf sign and it is pathognomonic of a simple bone cyst.

The trapdoor sign is a variant of the fallen leaf sign. Here, a periosteal hinge keeps the fragment from falling dependently and allows it to change position with a change in the patient's position.

questions.text: Which is the most common site for peripheral aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Femoral and popliteal artery aneurysms account for more than 90% of peripheral aneurysms, with popliteal artery aneurysms being the most common (70%).

Two-thirds of popliteal artery aneurysms are bilateral.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic. You do a bimanual examination by placing 2 fingers of one hand in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. This is called :
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question is the demonstration of Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.

This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

Other options :

Option A - Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination. It is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C - Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D - Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with pain, numbness, and fatigue of the right arm. Angiography reveals decreased flow through the vessels anastomosing near the surgical neck of the humerus. The pathology is likely to be present in which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The branches of the third part of the axillary artery supply the surgical neck of the humerus. Thrombus in this part will cause decreased supply in its branches - the anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries.

Branches of 3rd part of the axillary artery are:

  • Anterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Posterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Subscapular artery (not involved in the anastomosis)

Fracture of the surgical neck is the commonest site among all proximal humerus fractures due to its inherent weakness. Fracture at this site may cause injury to the posterior circumflex humeral artery and the axillary nerve that accompanies it.

Positional compression of the axillary artery is seen in athletes who are involved with throwing movement, as in baseball players. Repeated movement of the humerus may cause compression of the distal part of the axillary artery. This may lead to thrombosis or aneurysm resulting in arm ischemia.

questions.text: False about polyarteritis nodosa is __________

It is a disease of medium sized arteries

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy developed abnormal jerking movements that started in his left hand and gradually involved the entire arm. questions.text: An asymptomatic 30-year-old man presents with a lesion on his thigh as seen in the below image. He returned a week ago from the US where he inspected farming areas during the summer. The best management for this patient would be:

choices.text: Reassurance as it is a fixed drug eruption

questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts the bull’s eye lesion (erythema chronicum migrans) and the clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The drug of choice for early asymptomatic Lyme disease is Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It usually occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms. Most of them do not recall the bite and the initial presentation is only a skin lesion known as erythema chronicum migrans.

It is only after dissemination, that the disease spreads to joints (arthritis), heart (AV blocks), and the nervous system (neuroborreliosis).

The treatment protocol for early Lyme disease includes:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD (Drug of choice) for 2-3 weeks (or)
  • Amoxicillin 500 – 1000 mg for 2-3 weeks (for children < 9 years, pregnant women)

In severe disseminated cases, Ceftriaxone 2 g IV for 2-3 weeks can be given. 

Other options:

Option A - Chloroquine and tafenoquine are used to prevent Plasmodium vivax malaria relapse. There are no clinical symptoms suggestive of Malaria. 

Option C - Antihistamines can be used to treat urticaria. Patients present with short-lived itchy weals, angioedema, or both. 

Option D - Fixed drug eruption presents as a sharply defined oval or round erythematous, edematous plaque. It becomes dusky, violaceous, and vesicular or bullous. It occurs in the lips, genitals, palms, and soles.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a sore throat and difficulty swallowing for 2 days. On oropharyngeal examination, a grey-white membrane is observed over the tonsils. All of the following are differential diagnoses for membrane over the tonsils except
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned options are the differential diagnosis for membrane over the tonsils except Ludwig’s angina. Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space.

The differential diagnosis for grey membrane over the tonsils includes the following

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

 The image given below shows acute tonsillitis presenting with a membrane over the tonsil.

The image given below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

The image given below shows oral candidiasis.

Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space. The space lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other. It is most commonly caused by dental infections

Clinically, patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. On examination, the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular space becomes swollen, tender, and has a woody-hard feel.

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the clinic after he experienced palpitations. He has a history of ischemic heart disease.  His ECG findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows atrial fibrillation. On physical examination of his jugular venous pressure, absent 'a' waves will be noted. 

The following features in the ECG strip suggest the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation:

  • Presence of fibrillatory 'f' waves is indicative of uncoordinated atrial activation. Normal morphology P waves (indicative of normal atrial contraction) are absent
  • The QRS complex duration is <120 ms, which is normal. A narrow QRS complex indicates that the impulses are originating from the atria
  • R waves (QRS complex) occur irregularly, indicative of a variable RR interval. The rhythm is irregular (the pace is set by the refractory period of the AV node)

The 'a' wave is the first peak on a JVP tracing. It represents the atrial contraction (atrial systole). The rapid impulses of atrial fibrillation do not allow enough time for atrial filling and atrial contraction, leading to absent 'a' waves on JVP. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the hospital due to hoarseness of voice and dyspnea. Laryngoscopic examination revealed that the vocal cords were in the paramedian position. The woman is diagnosed with a nerve palsy. Which of the following is the most common cause of this kind of palsy?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. Surgical trauma is the most common cause for bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.

The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy and less for near-total procedures. Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy presents with hoarseness, and in severe cases aphonia. Since it supplies the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles which is the only abductor of the vocal cords, damage to this nerve results in the cord being in a paramedian position.

A 20-year retrospective study of causes of vocal fold immobility shows that neck surgery has become the most common cause of vocal fold paralysis over the past 10 years.

Note : Previously, extralaryngeal malignancies had been the most common cause which included Lung (50%), Oesophagus, Thyroid, Larynx.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was admitted to the ICU after major surgery for bowel cancer. Identify the false statement with respect to the test performed on this patient, which is shown below.

choices.text: This test is positive in deep vein thrombosis
The test is positive if there is calf pain on dorsiflexion of foot
It is highly sensitive and specific

questions.solution:
The image shows the method of eliciting Homan’s sign, that is calf pain on forced ankle dorsiflexion seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT). It is neither sensitive nor specific.

Endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and stasis of blood are the 3 components of Virchow's triad, which explains the formation of DVT. Postoperative thrombosis is the most common cause.

It presents with pain and swelling of the affected limb. Pitting edema, dilated veins, and low-grade fever are also present. Moses sign—tenderness on gently squeezing the calf—can be elicited. Embolization to the lungs can present as cyanosis, dyspnea, and dilated neck veins.

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of DVT, which shows filling defects and lack of compressibility.

The patient should be started on anticoagulants like heparin/low-molecular-weight heparin or fondaparinux.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text: Which phase of migrating motor complex (MMC) shows irregular electrical activity?
questions.solution:
Phase 2 of migrating motor complex (MMC) shows irregular electrical activity.

Migrating motor complex:

  • It is a type of motility in the intestine that occurs during fasting between periods of digestion.
  • They are initiated by motilin.
  • These cycles (MMC) migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum at a rate of about 5 cm/min and occur at intervals of approximately 90-100 minutes.
  • They likely serve to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal.
  • Upon ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished. The MMC resumes 90-120 minutes after a meal.
  • Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases
    • Phase I - Quiescent period
    • Phase II - Period of irregular electrical and mechanical activity
    • Phase III - Ends with bursts of regular activity

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
Among atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone and amisulpride have a higher risk of galactorrhoea.

Tuberoinfundibular neurons project from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary. Dopamine is delivered in this region via the hypophyseal vessels. Dopamine binds to the D2 receptors present on the lactotropes in the anterior pituitary, and tonically inhibits the prolactin secretion from these cells. 

The more potent a D2 blocking drug is, the more likely it is to cause hyperprolactinemia. All first-generation antipsychotic drugs cause hyperprolactinemia due to their D2 blocking properties. Among the atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone, and amisulpride are associated with hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia can induce breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and infertility in women, and sexual dysfunction in men.

questions.text: A 67 year old woman with a malignant lump in the breast who is undergoing chemotherapy, presents with shortness of breath, tachycardia and hypertension. ECG shows ST and T wave changes. Which among the following drugs could have led to this?
questions.solution:
This scenario depicts Doxorubicin induced cardiotoxicity. It is a unique adverse effect of doxorubicin. It is an anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics.

Doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy takes two forms:

  • Acute: pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome, arrhythmias, ST and T wave changes in ECG.
  • Chronic: dilated cardiomyopathy.

Note: Dexrazoxane is a cardioprotective iron-chelating agent that is indicated for use along with high dose doxorubicin to avoid cardiotoxicity.

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby weighing 15 kg was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. He is afebrile, and there is no blood in his stools. The baby is lethargic. On examination, the eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retraction took more than two seconds. On offering water the child does not show eagerness to drink and responds poorly. Which of the following is correct concerning the treatment of dehydration in this child?

choices.text: 600 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour
600 ml to be given as IV in the first  half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour

questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has severe dehydration, as indicated by lethargy, and sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (>2 seconds). 450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour is correct for the treatment of dehydration in this child.

Severe dehydration requires treatment plan C. This involves using intravenous fluids (ringer lactate with 5% dextrose).

15 kg x 30 mL/kg = 450 ml fluids in the first half-hour, and

15 kg x 70 mL/kg = 1050 ml over the next 2.5 hours.

questions.text: Which cells have a defensive function and also serve as progenitor cells?
questions.solution:
Clara cells/club cells have a defensive function and also serve as progenitor cells.

Clara cells are non-ciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete important defense markers and serve as stem cells after injury. These cells make up a larger portion of the epithelial lining in the later portions of the conducting airway.

Other options:

Options A and B: Type I and type II pneumocytes are seen in the alveolar epithelium. Type I cells are responsible for gas exchange whereas type II cells produce surfactants.

Option D: Kulchitsky cells are the neuroendocrine cells present in the bronchial mucosa of the lungs. These cells have neurosecretory-type granules and can release a variety of factors including serotonin, calcitonin, and gastrin-releasing peptide (bombesin).

questions.text: A baby born to a woman taking prophylactic medication for manic disorder is cyanotic, lethargic, and hypotonic. Which other finding is the baby most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in Ebstein's anomaly. This is a rare congenital cyanotic heart disease caused by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. It is a teratogenic effect of lithium, a drug used for prophylaxis in manic disorder.

Lithium is thus avoided in the first trimester and during lactation. An antipsychotic like olanzapine should be considered instead of prophylactic management.

If lithium is to be continued, then:

  • The dose should be tapered to the lower end of the therapeutic range
  • It should be given in divided doses
  • The levels should be checked every two weeks
  • The woman should be hydrated well throughout labour
  • Withholding lithium therapy for 24-48 hours before delivery is recommended

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man who sustained trauma to the scrotal area a few days back came to the hospital with sudden onset of pain in the perineal and scrotal area, with blackening of the scrotum, as shown in the image. Which of the following statement is false with respect to this condition?

choices.text: It is usually not a surgical emergency.
Alcoholism is a predisposing factor for this condition.
It occurs due to a mixed infection with aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and image showing black, necrotic skin over an inflamed scrotum indicate that the patient has Fournier's gangrene, and it is a surgical emergency. 

Fournier's gangrene is characterized by a polymicrobial infection of the soft tissue of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. It is necrotizing fasciitis with rapid onset gangrene, which leads to the exposure of the scrotal contents.

Concurrent illnesses that diminish the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus, and alcoholism, predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene. It may occur after minor injuries or procedures done in the perineal region.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: a mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene formation

It presents with sudden pain, pyrexia, and prostration. There may be a foul-smelling exudate and crepitus may be present. The testes are usually not affected. Cellulitis spreads and involves the skin and coverings of the scrotum, and penis. This may get sloughed and expose the testes, which remain healthy. It is also referred to as "shameful exposure of the testis." 

It is a surgical emergency.

  • Initial management is by intravenous (IV) fluid resuscitation and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Urgent wide surgical excision of dead and infected tissue is essential.

Despite the best therapy, mortality rates have been reported to be as high as 50%.

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Miller laryngoscopic blade. 

A laryngoscope is an instrument used for examination of the larynx and facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source. The Macintosh and Miller blades are the most popularly used blades.

Miller's blade is a straight blade. Its curve begins 2 inches from the tip. It is inserted using the para-glossal technique. This technique avoids contact with the maxillary incisors and provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. It is inserted in the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. The blade is advanced and positioned in the vallecula. Advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy was brought to the well-baby clinic for routine immunization. He has a weight for height less than 2 standard deviations below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition.

Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry

  • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. 
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population.
  • Low weight for the age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Note:

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening wasting in children.

questions.text: All of the following delay healing except _______
questions.solution:
The activation of Lysyl hydroxylases promotes healing. Vitamin C activates prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases from inactive precursors, which helps in the hydroxylation of procollagen.

Inadequately hydroxylated procollagen cannot acquire a stable helical configuration, so it is poorly secreted from the fibroblast. Molecules secreted in this manner are poorly cross-linked, lack tensile strength, and are more soluble and vulnerable to enzymatic degradation.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is common for both gluconeogenesis and glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Enolase is common for both gluconeogenesis and glycolysis. Enolase catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, which is a reversible step.

Enzymes catalyzing irreversible steps in gluconeogenesis and glycolysis cannot be the common enzyme for both.

The irreversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Hexokinase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate kinase

The irreversible steps of gluconeogenesis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase
  • Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase

questions.text: The COVID-19 outbreak is a type of ______________.
questions.solution:
This outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a propagated epidemic.

The propagated epidemic results from a person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. In this scenario, the cases of COVID occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease. Other examples of a propagated epidemic include Hepatitis A and Polio.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is single exposure from a point source.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposures epidemics:

Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time

Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

questions.text: A man with severe burn injuries is admitted to the ward. Proton-pump inhibitors are started. Which ulcer is being prevented?
questions.solution:
Proton pump inhibitors are used in burns patients to prevent Curling's ulcer. It is an acute gastric erosion that is a complication from severe burns when reduced plasma volume leads to ischemia and cell necrosis of the gastric mucosa.

Marjolin’s Ulcer is squamous cell carcinoma occurring in a long-standing burn scar or any chronic ulcer.

Cushing’s ulcer is a gastric ulcer occurring in elevated intracranial pressure.

Buruli's Ulcer is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans.

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions requires treatment with pulsatile doses of GnRH agonists?
questions.solution:
The pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in the treatment of male infertility.

Pulsatile administration of GnRH agonist increases FSH and LH secretion and is used to treat male and female infertility.

A non-pulsatile or a continuous dose of GnRH agonist results in suppression and decreased concentrations of gonadotropins (LH and FSH). Hence, it cannot be used in the treatment of male infertility. 

Non-pulsatile (Continuous) administration of GnRH analogs used in: 

  • Endometriosis
  • Uterine fibroids
  • Central precocious puberty
  • Ca prostate
  • Ca ovary and breast
  • Controlled ovary stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the image given below :

choices.text: Maternal diabetes is a risk factor
Application of fundal pressure aids delivery

questions.solution:
The image depicts shoulder dystocia and never apply fundal pressure in case of shoulder dystocia as it causes further impaction of the shoulder.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, postdatism, and prior history, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.

Turtle Sign is positive: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. The baby's cheeks bulge out, resembling a turtle pulling its head back into its shell. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing the delivery of the remainder of the baby.

Management of shoulder dystocia

  • 1st line - Mc.Roberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of thigh)
  • 2nd line - Woods corkscrew maneuver (Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion)
  • 3rd line management options include:
    • Zavanelli maneuver (Push the head back and do a C-Section)
    • Cleidotomy (#clavicle of baby)
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

Note:

  • In the case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform a C-section after doing the Zavanelli maneuver.
  • Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

questions.text: While taking ward rounds, you come across the ECG of a patient which looks as given below. Which of the following can cause such an ECG?
questions.solution:
In the above ECG, there is a depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, a slightly prolonged PR interval, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of hypokalemia, which can be seen when giving insulin infusion due to the intracellular shift of potassium. 

Hypokalemia can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Other options:

Option A: Vit A can cause hypercalcemia. It will show a shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration in ECG. 

Option B: Bisphosphonate overdose is associated with hypocalcemia. It shows prolongation of the QT interval due to lengthening of the ST segment. The QT interval prolongation is proportional to the degree of hypocalcemia. The T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Below image shows prolonged QT interval in hypocalcemia

Option C: ACE inhibitors cause hyperkalemia.

ECG changes in hyperkalemia. Different changes are seen according to the levels of potassium.

  • Tall peaked T waves are present when the serum potassium levels are 5.5–6.5 mmol/L. 
  • Loss of P waves are seen when the concentration is between 6.5–7.5 mmol/L.
  • Widened QRS complex is seen when the concentration is between 7.0–8.0 mmol/L
  • Sine wave pattern when concentration is >8.0 mmol/L

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OHA intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Other options:

Option A - Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Option C - Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option D - Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where,

  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.

questions.text: A known cardiac patient was advised not to take omeprazole while he is on clopidogrel medication. What is the liver enzyme common to the metabolism of these drugs?

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed to have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. The ENT specialist decides that a cochlear implant would be the best treatment for this patient. Which of the following is true about the cochlear implant?

choices.text: Indicated in severe sensorineural and conductive hearing loss
The implant is placed in the roof of the fourth ventricle
Electrode is placed in the scala media of the cochlea
Intact 8th cranial nerve and higher auditory pathway are prerequisites

questions.solution:
An intact 8th cranial nerve and intact higher auditory pathway are prerequisites for a cochlear implant.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and those who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It works by directly stimulating the auditory nerve and bypassing the cochlear hair cells that are damaged. 

The principle of the surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. An intact 8th nerve and the higher auditory pathway are prerequisites for surgery.

Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique. The facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach is preferred. An auditory brainstem implant is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.

The candidates for a cochlear implant should have the following features

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Less or no benefit from hearing aids
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery
  4. Realistic expectation
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device

Other devices used in the management of hearing loss are:

  • Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, conductive deafness not amenable to other treatment procedures.
  • Stapedectomy piston, used in patients with otosclerosis.
  • Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes are structurally intact.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: In the clinical ward rounds, the professor tests the vibratory sensations of a patient by placing a 128Hz tuning fork on his great toe. He explains the receptors involved rapidly adapt to ongoing stimuli. Which receptor is he referring to?
questions.solution:
Rapidly adapting receptors that sense 128 Hz (fast vibration) are Pacinian corpuscles.

Pacinian corpuscles are cutaneous mechanoreceptors, which consist of unmyelinated dendritic endings of a sensory nerve fiber, encapsulated by concentric lamellae of connective tissue. It gives them an onion peel-like appearance. They respond to deep pressure and fast vibration of frequencies ranging between 60 - 300 Hz. Pacinian corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors, adapting in a few hundredths of a second.

The below image shows the histology of the Pacinian corpuscle.

Other options : 

Option A - Merkel's discs are expanded dendritic endings, which respond to sustained pressure and touch. They are slow-adapting receptors, allowing one to determine the continuous touch of objects against the skin.

Option B - Ruffini's end organs are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules. These adapt very slowly and therefore, are important for signaling continuous states of deformation of the tissues, such as heavy prolonged touch and pressure signals. They are also found in joint capsules and help to signal the degree of joint rotation.

Option D - Meissner’s corpuscles are elongated encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber. They are abundant in the nonhairy parts of the skin (lips, fingertips). Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors, particularly sensitive to the movement of objects over the surface of the skin, as well as to low-frequency vibration (5-40 Hz).

questions.text: When the caregiver is overtly critical, hostile and overinvolved with a patient with schizophrenia, the relapse rate is high. This phenomenon is termed as ________
questions.solution:
When parents or other caregivers behave with overt criticism, hostility, or overinvolvement towards a person with schizophrenia, which further worsens the illness, this phenomenon is called expressed emotions.

Marital schism, marital skew, expressed emotions and double-bind refer to abnormalities of family dynamics.

3. Double bind - a hypothetical family in which children receive conflicting parental messages about their behavior, attitudes, and feelings.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement with regard to puerperal involution?

choices.text: Immediately after delivery, the fundus is just below the umbilicus
Total number of myocytes decreases drastically postpartum
Uterus becomes a pelvice organ by the end of 2 weeks postpartum
Sonographically, uterus returns to pregravid size by 8 weeks postpartum

questions.solution:
The total number of myocytes does not decrease appreciably-rather, their size decreases markedly during the postpartum period.

Puerperal involution:

  • Immediately after delivery, the fundus is just below the umbilicus (20 weeks gestational age size).
  • After 24 hours of delivery, the height of the uterus decreases by 1.25cm/day.
  • The uterus becomes a pelvic organ by the end of 2 weeks.
  • The uterus returns to its normal size (pre-pregnant size) by the end of 8 weeks.
  • Involution occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibres (not the number).

questions.text: Costovertebral angle is formed between ________

choices.text: Lower border of 11th rib  and  the  lateral border of erector spinae
Lower border of the 12th rib and  the vertebral column
Lower border of the 12th rib and  the  lateral border of erector spinae
Lower border of 11th rib  and  the  vertebral column

questions.solution:
The costovertebral angle is formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 

Clinical note: The following conditions cause pain/tenderness in the region of the costovertebral angle.

  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS)

The angle between the lower border of the 12th rib and the lateral border of the erector spinae (sacrospinalis) muscle is known as the renal angle. The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.text: What is the metallic shielding used in MRI rooms called?
questions.solution:
MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper called Faraday cage, which provides radiofrequency (RF) shielding.

Faraday cage is a conductive box used to shield out stray electromagnetic interference. It is most commonly made of wood panels wrapped with copper. Other metals like aluminium and galvanized steel can also be used. It serves two functions:

  • To prevent external radiofrequency pulses from interfering with the detector
  • To prevent radiofrequency pulses generated by the scanner from interfering with the external environment

questions.text: What is the most common presenting symptom of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group?
questions.solution:
The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility.

Genital tuberculosis mostly presents in young women in the reproductive age group. It can present as:

  • Infertility is the only complaint in 35-60 % of cases. Of these, 75% of women present with primary infertility.
  • Menstrual abnormalities are seen in 10-40% of cases.
  • Asymptomatic in 10% of cases.
  • Other symptoms like fever and malaise can be seen.

The treatment of infertility in women with genital TB depends on the condition of the endometrium. If the endometrium is receptive and the uterus is normal, then assisted reproductive techniques such as in-vitro fertilisation can be tried. If the endometrium is unfavourable then surrogacy may be considered.

questions.text: The appearance of fibers in the histological image below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rosenthal fibers, which are commonly associated with pilocytic astrocytoma.

A Rosenthal fiber is a thick, elongated, worm-like, or "corkscrew" eosinophilic bundle that is found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long-standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders. It is usually associated with pilocytic astrocytoma (more common) or Alexander's disease (a rare leukodystrophy).

Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma or juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma or cystic cerebellar astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults (in the first 20 years of life).
  • These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The neoplasms are associated with the formation of a single (or multiple) cyst(s) and can become very large.
  • Diagnosis can be made on the basis of brain MRI findings. Surgery is usually the treatment of choice. Total resection is often possible.

questions.text: A 44-year-old lady, presented with tender erythematous shiny plaques over the shin as shown in the image. What is the type of hypersensitivity(HSN) reaction seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical description of tender erythematous shiny plaques over the shin along with the image is suggestive of Erythema nodosum. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. 

Histopathologically, erythema nodosum predominantly shows septal panniculitis without vasculitis.

Erythema nodosum

The most common infectious cause of erythema nodosum is group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

Aetiological factors in erythema nodosum:

  • Infections: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, tuberculosis, leprosy, brucella, toxoplasmosis, mycoplasma pneumonia, CMV, E.coli, yersinia, tuberculosis
  • Idiopathic, pregnancy
  • Drugs including oral contraceptives, hormonal replacement therapy, sulphonamides, and penicillin
  • Sarcoidosis, Sweet syndrome, SLE, RA, Reiter's syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease
  • Malignancy

Pathophysiology:

Erythema nodosum is the result of a non-specific cutaneous reaction to various antigens. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. 

Clinical features:

The prodromal phase includes fever, joint, and muscle pains, and an alteration in general health. It is followed by the development of painful, tender, nodules on the extensor surfaces of legs. knees and forearms. It usually resolves spontaneously in about 10 days. Treatment is mostly supportive.

questions.text: Identify the drug which causes this adverse effect ________
questions.solution:
Ergotamine causes occlusion of peripheral blood vessels in susceptible persons. It acts as a partial agonist and antagonist at α adrenoreceptors and all subtypes of 5HT1 and 5HT2 serotonin receptors.

The numbness progressing to bluish discoloration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can lead to gangrene if left untreated eventually leading to amputation. Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of ergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine: 

  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: Identify the position of the fetus in the following image:
questions.solution:
The fetus is in right acromiodorsoanterior position (the shoulder of the fetus is to the mother's right, and the back is anterior.

The position of the fetus in a transverse lie is determined by the direction of the back, which is the denominator.

The position may be:

  • Dorsoanterior, which is the most common (60%). 
  • Dorsoposterior, where the chance of fetal extension is common with increased risk of arm prolapse
  • Dorsosuperior or
  • Dorsoinferior

The last two are rare.

Transverse lie :

  • The fetal presentation in a transverse lie is shoulder presentation.
  • The most common cause of transverse lies is prematurity.
  • The most common cause of transverse lies in term pregnancy is placenta previa.
  • The most common cause of cord prolapse is a transverse lie.
  • Hand prolapse is frequently seen in transverse lie.
  • A transverse lie is managed by caesarean section.
  • Management of neglected shoulder presentation is caesarean section.
  • Management of 1st twin with the transverse lie is caesarean section.
  • Management of 2nd twin with the transverse lie is Internal podalic version.

questions.text: Which of the following patients is most likely to develop thyroid storm?

choices.text: A 45 year old man with Grave's disease and pneumonia
A 32 year old woman with toxic nodule and no complaints
A 27 year old woman with long-standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis on treatment
A 56 year old man with TSH secreting adenoma and no complaints

questions.solution:
Thyroid storm occurs most commonly in patients with underlying Grave's disease probably due to an acute elevation in catecholamine levels during infection, surgery, cessation of antithyroid medication, or any form of stress.

Thyroid storm refers to the abrupt onset of severe hyperthyroidism. It is a medical emergency where a significant number of untreated patients die of cardiac arrhythmias.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: According to the National Strategic Plan for Malarialimination in India 2017-2022, the Annual Parasite Index(API) of 1 - 2 per 1000 population comes under _____________
questions.solution:
According to the National Strategic Plan for Malaria elimination in India 2017-2022, the Annual Parasite Index(API) of 1 - 2 per 1000 population comes under the pre-elimination phase.

The annual parasite Incidence is calculated as:

(Cases in one year ×1000) / Population under surveillance

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: The communication of a disease from one person to another by close contact is called __________
questions.solution:
Contagion is the communication of a disease from one person to another by close contact.

Infection is the entry and development or multiplication of an infectious agent in another organism.

Infestation is the lodgement, development, and reproduction of arthropods on the surface. It also includes invasion of the gut by parasitic worms.

Contamination is the presence of a disease agent on a body surface like clothes, toys, etc. and also in substances like food or water.

questions.text: Thoracic duct does not drain:
questions.solution:
Right upper quadrant of the body drains the lymphatics into the right lymphatic trunk and rest of the body drains into the thoracic duct.

Thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at T-12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli.

  • It is usually beaded due to its numerous valves.
  • It drains the body below the diaphragm (lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen) and left half of the body above the diaphragm (thorax, upper limb, head and neck).
  • Thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm and ascends through the posterior mediastinum between the aorta and the azygous vein.
  • At T-5 level, it deviates to the left side and ascends to pass the thoracic inlet.

Tributaries of the thoracic duct:

  • Bilateral (right and left) descending thoracic lymph trunks which convey lymph from lower intercostal spaces (6 – 11).
  • Left upper intercostal lymph trunks, which convey lymph from the upper intercostal spaces (1-5).
  • Mediastinal lymph trunks
  • Left subclavian lymph trunk
  • Left jugular lymph trunk
  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

questions.text: Severe postpartum haemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than _____ mL of blood after completion of the third stage of labor (in vaginal delivery).
questions.solution:
Severe postpartum haemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than 2000 mL of blood after completion of third stage of labour (in vaginal delivery).

Postpartum haemorrhag (PPH) is defined as a loss of more than 500 ml of blood after completion of the third stage of labor (in vaginal delivery).

PPH is blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract following cesarean section.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be, minor (<1L) or major (>1L). Major is further subdivided into moderate (1L-2L) and severe (>2L).

Recent Update :

PPH is classically defined by the volume of blood loss. But this definition will soon become obsolete as the bleeding may not be visible externally, or the blood in collection devices may be mixed with amniotic fluid.

In 2017, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists revised their definition of PPH to

  • Cumulative blood loss of ≥1000 mL or 
  • Bleeding associated with signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of the birth process (regardless of the route of delivery).

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is a multipennate?
questions.solution:
Deltoid is a multipennate muscle.

Muscles with oblique fibers are subclassified as follows:

  • Pennate: They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
    • Unipennate: Fascicles on one side of the tendon. E.g., flexor pollicis longus, extensor digitorum longus, peroneus tertius, and, palmar interossei.
    • Bipennate: Fascicles on two sides of the tendon. E.g., rectus femoris, peroneus longus, flexor hallucis longus, and dorsal interossei.
    • Multipennate: Central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle. E.g., deltoid, subscapularis
    • Circumpennate (radial): Muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion. E.g., tibialis anterior
  • Triangular: They are triangular in shape. E.g., temporalis, adductor longus, and trapezius.

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.solution:
The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) increases with standing, as there is a reduction in preload. In conditions of reduced preload, there is lesser end diastolic volume in the left ventricle, leading to a narrower outflow tract, and a louder murmur is heard.

The murmur heard in HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur, which is loudest along the left sternal border. It increases in conditions of decreased preload and afterload (standing, valsalva, vagal maneuvers) or conditions of increased contractility (inotropic stimulation) and decreases when preload and afterload are increased (squatting, vasopressors).

Most murmurs decrease in intensity with reduced preload and afterload except HOCM and mitral valve prolapse (MVP).

  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur

questions.text: A 7-year-old child abruptly developed symptoms suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder and Tourette syndrome. PANDAS, a pediatric neuropsychiatric disorder, is suspected. Which of the following organisms is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
PANDAS is associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection.

PANDAS stands for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections.

The symptoms usually occur abruptly and can include the following:

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
  • Tic disorder
  • Gilles de la Tourette syndrome (coprolalia and tics)

Additionally, children may become moody or irritable, experience anxiety attacks, and/or show separation anxiety. These symptoms are the result of an autoimmune process that leads to inflammation of the basal ganglia and the resultant disruption of cortical-striatal-thalamic axis functioning.

Features:

  • Prepubertal onset
  • Abrupt and episodic course
  • Neurological symptoms
  • Disorders associated: Tics, OCD
  • Associated with a recent history of sore throat

Note: Non-infectious manifestations of streptococcal infection:

  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • PANDAS
  • Guttate psoriasis

questions.text: The gross specimen of the pancreas from a patient who died of acute pancreatitis is shown below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given specimen shows yellow nodules with areas of chalky-white deposits, which are suggestive of fat necrosis.

Fat necrosis results from the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification).

Histologic examination reveals foci of shadowy outlines of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic calcium deposits, surrounded by an inflammatory reaction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with severe pain in the buttocks extending down the back of the right leg. MRI revealed inflammation of the muscle shown in the image. Which of the following nerves is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
The muscle shown in the image is piriformis. The clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome that is characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle. Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

 The muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It is inserted into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibers or above the muscle.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female came to OPD with a history of a lump in the right breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the right breast is 5 × 6 cm and has right-side interpectoral axillary lymphadenopathy. Interpectoral axillary lymph node belongs to ___________

Level 3 group of axillary lymph nodes
Level 2 group of axillary lymph nodes

questions.text: A previously untreated HIV-positive patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis and treatment is initiated for both the diseases. Two weeks into treatment, he suddenly complains of high fever, severe malaise and worsening cough. What is the likely explanation?

choices.text: Bacterial endotoxin release due to death of TB bacilli

questions.solution:
Concurrent treatment with anti-retroviral therapy is the most likely explanation in this case resulting in Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). Its characteristics are:

  • Temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms (lymphadenopathy, fever or worsening of pulmonary infiltrations, pleural effusion) and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ART. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT. 
  • It is seen weeks to months following the initiation of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART).
  • It is most common in previously untreated patients starting therapy with a CD4+ T cell count <50/μL who experience a sudden drop in viral load.
  • The earlier ART is started and the lower the baseline CD4+ T-cell count, the greater the risk of IRIS.
  • In severe cases, the use of immunosuppressive drugs such as glucocorticoids may be required to blunt the inflammatory component of IRIS while specific antimicrobial therapy takes effect.

Note: Hypersensitivity to isoniazid is extremely rare and the presentation includes maculopapular rash.

questions.text: A patient with toxic adenoma is being prepared for surgery. Which of the following statements is wrong regarding this?

choices.text: Iodine may be given pre-operatively with carbimazole
Beta blockers administered pre-operatively must be continued post operatively
Nadolol is given in a once daily regimen pre-operatively
The last dose of carbimazole must be given 24 hours before surgery

questions.solution:
The last dose of carbimazole may be given the evening before surgery.

Toxic adenoma is a benign functioning thyroid tumour, which usually presents as a toxic solitary nodule. It is an autonomously functioning tumour that does not respond to TSH. Treatment involves antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine. This is followed by hemithyroidectomy as the surrounding normal thyroid tissue regains normal function.

Traditional preparation of a thyrotoxic patient aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid. There are two methods of preparation that can be used:

  1. Carbimazole 30-40 mg per day is the drug of choice. When euthyroid (after 8-12 weeks), the dose may be reduced. Beta-blockers, if used preoperatively, must be given on the morning of surgery and continued for a week post-op.
  2. Propranolol 40 mg TDS or a longer-acting nadolol 160 mg once daily may be given to achieve beta-blockade. It is important to continue treatment up to 7 days postoperatively.

Iodine may be given with carbimazole or a beta-blocker 10 days before the operation. It produces transient remission and reduces thyroid vascularity.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: A chronically ill patient is found to have anemia. All the following are true about anemia of chronic disease except:

choices.text: May be seen in association with Hodgkin lymphoma
Interleukin-6 stimulates increase in production of hepcidin in this condition
Low serum ferritin and increased  total iron-binding capacity is seen
Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages is seen

questions.solution:
Anemia of chronic disease shows high serum ferritin and reduced total iron-binding capacity.

Chronic diseases that produce persistent systemic inflammation can impair red cell production and thus cause anemia of chronic disease. This is due to decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors and impaired iron utilization.

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections- osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders- rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms- breast and lung carcinomas, Hodgkin lymphoma

Many effects of inflammation are related to the abnormalities seen in anemia of chronic disease. Inflammatory mediators, like interleukin-6 (IL-6), stimulate the production of hepcidin. Hepcidin inhibits ferroportin in macrophages. This reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to the bone marrow, where erythroid precursors are developing. In addition, erythroid progenitors cannot proliferate adequately because erythropoietin levels are inappropriately low for the level of anemia.

Clinical features include mild anemia, with the symptoms of the underlying disease. The red cells may be normocytic and normochromic, or hypochromic and microcytic. Increased storage iron in marrow macrophages, high serum ferritin, and a decreased total iron-binding capacity readily rule out the iron deficiency when the smear shows a microcytic hypochromic picture.
