A 60-year-old man was brought with a high-grade fever, productive cough, and confusion for the last 2 days. His vitals and chest radiograph are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

Temperature: 102°F

Pulse rate: 130 bpm

BP: 86/58 mmHg

Respiratory rate: 32/min

choices.text: Start oral antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and insert intercostal drainage tube
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and start IV antibiotics
Admit the patient in ICU and start IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever and productive cough and the chest radiograph showing lobar consolidation point to a diagnosis of pneumonia. Since this patient's CURB-65 score is at least 3 (1 point each for confusion, BP <90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate >30/min), the most appropriate management would be ICU admission and starting IV antibiotics.

Once the diagnosis of pneumonia is made, the next step in management is to determine the site of care for the patient. To identify the patients that require in-patient and ICU management, CURB-65 score is used. It includes:

  • Confusion
  • Urea ≥17 mg/dL
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • Blood pressure: SBP ≤90mmHg or DBP ≤60 mmHg
  • Age ≥ 65 years

1 point is given for the presence of each of the above. The total score determines the site of care, as shown below:

0 Outpatient treatment
1 or 2 Inpatient treatment in non-ICU setting

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He had headaches, nausea, and vertigo after the accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Typically unilateral (85%) 
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

 

Image 1: CT image of acute subdural hemorrhage

Image 2: CT image of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text:
A plastic surgeon is planning a split-skin grafting procedure. Arrange the following phases in the correct order during the take of the graft?
  1. Neovascularization
  2. Imbibition
  3. Adherence
  4. Inosculation
questions.solution:
The correct order of phases during the take of a split skin graft at a recipient site is: imbibition → inosculation → neovascularization → adherence.

During the first 48 hours following the placement of the graft on the recipient site, the graft survives by getting nourishment from the plasma exudate from the capillaries of the recipient bed. This is known as imbibition or plasmatic circulation. After 48 hours, the cut-ends of the blood vessels of both the graft and the recipient bed align together to form anastomoses. This phase is called inosculation. Neovascularization refers to the in-growth of the blood vessels from the recipient site into the graft. The organization of the graft begins immediately following the placement of the graft due to the formation of a fibrin layer. The graft becomes adherent to the bed by days 10-14.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: Which of the following region of mRNA offers protection from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity?
questions.solution:
The poly(A) tail protects the 3′ end of mRNA from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease attack and facilitates translation.

Eukaryotic messenger RNA usually undergoes post-transcriptional modification and polyadenylation is an important part of this post-transcriptional modification. They help to stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened.  Eukaryotic mRNAs have poly-A tails at 3' end and 7-methylguanosine caps at 5' end.

Other options:

Option A: The attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the guanyl cap at the 5' end. It also prevents the attack of 5′→ 3′ exonucleases

Option B: TATA box is the site of pre-initiation complex formation, which is the first step in transcription initiation.

Option D: Shine-Dalgarno sequence initiates translation in prokaryotes.

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes to painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. The light reflex of the right and left eye are shown. His GCS-P score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS-P (Glasgow Coma Scale with pupil reactivity score) score in this patient is 9.

In this case,

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to a painful stimulus only.
  • The motor score for flexing limbs in response to a painful stimulus is 4 and localising the pain stimulus is 5. However, only the highest score (i.e. score for the best performance elicited) will be taken into account. Therefore, the score for best motor response is 5.

Therefore, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is (4+2+5) = 11.

The image demonstrates the absence of pupillary constriction on exposure to light and the inference is "both the pupils not reactive to light". So, the pupil reactivity score (P) is 2.

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value of GCS-P. Therefore, the GCS-P score is 11-2 = 9.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

Minimum value: 3

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

One pupil 1

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Atheromatous plaques are associated with dystrophic calcification. This is seen in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type. Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis.

questions.text: An infant with Edward's syndrome presents with the following radiological finding. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Mostly presents as vomiting within 1 week
Erythromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life can lead to this condition
Palpation of the pyloric olive is pathognomonic  for this condition

questions.solution:
The radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting between 2-8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks.

Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.

Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Turner syndrome
  • Edwards syndrome
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk.

Palpation of the olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium is considered pathognomonic. 

USG criteria for diagnosing hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm or a pyloric length >15-18 mm in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction is diagnostic.

questions.text: What type of study is shown below?
questions.solution:
The study shown is a prospective cohort study. 

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. It can be divided into:

  • Prospective cohort studies: Outcome has not occurred at the time of the beginning of the investigation 
  • Retrospective cohort studies: Outcome has occurred before the beginning of the investigation 
  • Combination cohort studies: Both retrospective and prospective elements are combined

A cohort is a group of individuals who share a common experience or characteristic within a defined time period. The cohort groups are selected before the appearance of the disease under investigation. They are divided into study and control cohorts. The study cohorts are exposed to a particular factor thought to be related to the disease occurrence whereas the control cohorts are not exposed to this particular factor.  

Studying the effects of exposure to uranium in causing lung cancer is an example of a cohort study. Uranium miners are taken as the study cohort and other individuals who are not exposed to uranium mining are taken as the control cohort. 

Note: In a nested case-control study, cases of disease that have occurred in a defined cohort are identified. A specified number of matched controls who have not developed the disease are then selected from the cohort. 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: An obese diabetic female patient is posted for surgery. The anesthetist performs a BURP maneuver during intubation. Identify the true statement regarding this maneuver.

choices.text: It is a technique of internal laryngeal manipulation.
It is useful for rapid-sequence induction.
It is a method of assessment of airway.
In this technique, pressure is applied on the thyroid cartilage.

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the BURP maneuver is that pressure is applied to the thyroid cartilage.

BURP is a technique of external laryngeal manipulation of the airway during intubation for better visualization of the larynx. This involves Backward, Upward, and Rightward Pressure on the thyroid cartilage.

The illustration shown below shows the BURP maneuver.

Other options : 

Option B: The BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

Option C: BURP is not a method of assessment of the airway. Various methods of airway assessments are Mallampati grading, Cormack and Lehane grading, and Wilson’s scoring.

questions.text: Mullerian inhibiting substance is produced by:
questions.solution:
The Mullerian inhibiting substance is produced by the Ser­toli cells.

Sertoli cells produce the following substances:

  • The Mullerian inhibitory substance: Pre­vents the development of the Müllerian system.
  • Testosterone-binding protein: Maintains a high level of testosterone within the testis. This is necessary for continuous spermatogenesis.
  • Inhibin B: Inhibits FSH but stimulates LH secretion.

Testosterone is synthesized from cholesterol in the Leydig cells and also from androstenedione secreted by the adrenal cortex.

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, who is a known hypertensive, not on treatment, presents to the OPD for a regular checkup. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The presence of which of the following in him will help us diagnose metabolic syndrome, as per NCEP- ATP III?

choices.text: Triglycerides of 100 mg/dL and waist circumference of 105 cm
Waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL
Fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL and HDL cholesterol of 60 mg/dL
HDL Cholesterol of 60 mg/dL and triglycerides of 100 mg/dL

questions.solution:
In this patient with the blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg, a waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL helps diagnose metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education program and adult treatment panel III). It includes-

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: Confabulation is not seen in:

choices.text: Traumatic brain injury of frontal lobe

questions.solution:
Confabulation is not seen in psychogenic amnesia.

Confabulation refers to the unconscious filling of gaps in memory with inaccurate, fabricated, and often implausible information.

Psychogenic amnesia presents with a sudden onset of retrograde amnesia, a loss of personal identity, and minimal anterograde amnesia. It is also called hysterical amnesia or functional amnesia or dissociative amnesia.  

 Causes of confabulation:

  • Wernicke’s korsakoff syndrome 
  • Traumatic brain injury
  • Anton syndrome

Anton syndrome is characterized by cortical blindness with confabulation 

Anton syndrome occurs due to occipital lobe damage. Here, the patient denies loss of vision (known as visual anosognosia) and defends it by confabulation even when there is obvious evidence of visual loss and cortical blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following structure marked in the given image is involved in Millard Gubler syndrome?
questions.solution:
The structure no.3 that is marked in the given image is the abducens nerve (6th nerve). It is involved in Millard Gubler syndrome which results from basilar artery stroke. Millard Gubler syndrome is a pontine lesion affecting 6th, 7thcranial nerve, and fibers of corticospinal tract.

Features are:

  • 6th nerve: Diplopia, ipsilateral convergent squint 
  • 7th nerve:  Loss of corneal reflex, ipsilateral paralysis of facial muscles
  • Corticospinal tract: Contralateral hemiplegia of extremities (due to involvement of pyramidal tract).

questions.text: You are examining an 18-year-old woman and it appears she has mature adult breasts. What is the Tanner stage of breast development in her?
questions.solution: The Tanner staging of the breast, in case of mature adult breast, is denoted as B5.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be activated after a carbohydrate-rich meal?
questions.solution:
Only phosphofructokinase 2 will be activated after a meal.

Phosphofructokinase 2 is a bifunctional enzyme that can phosphorylate fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 2,6 bisphosphate during glycolysis. The same enzyme protein is also responsible for its breakdown since it has fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase activity.

When there is an abundant supply of glucose, the concentration of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate increases, stimulating glycolysis by activating phosphofructokinase-1 and inhibiting fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase. 

Other options:

HMG CoA lyase is an enzyme involved in ketogenesis which occurs during the fasting state.

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis which is favored by glucagon during the fasting state.

Insulin indirectly inhibits β-oxidation by activating acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis) and increasing the malonyl-CoA concentration in the cytoplasm, which inhibits carnitine acyltransferase (Fatty acid oxidation).

The image is showing characteristic Burtonian lines, which are seen in lead poisoning and mercury poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following risk factors is commonly associated with pelvic actinomycosis?
questions.solution:
Pelvic actinomycosis is commonly due to Intrauterine contraceptive device use.

Actinomyces israelii is a gram-positive, slow-growing, anaerobic bacterium that constitutes the normal vaginal flora. It is an uncommon cause of pelvic inflammatory disease in general.

Management includes antibiotic therapy while retaining the IUD in asymptomatic women. For those with symptoms, the IUD is removed and antibiotic therapy can be instituted.

questions.text: Which of the following nuclei do not belong to the general visceral efferent column?
questions.solution:
Nucleus ambiguus does not belong to the general visceral efferent (GVE) column.

The general visceral efferent columns contain nuclei of parasympathetic cranial nerves:

  • III - Edinger-Westphal nucleus
  • VII - Superior salivatory nucleus
  • IX - Inferior salivatory nucleus
  • X - Dorsal motor nucleus of vagus.

Nucleus ambiguus belongs to the special visceral efferent (SVE) column.

The special visceral efferent column contains neurons innervating muscles developed from the pharyngeal arches:

  • Motor nucleus of V nerve- muscles of mastication
  • Motor nucleus of VII nerve- muscles of facial expression
  • Nucleus ambiguus (IX, X, XI)- stylopharyngeus, pharyngeal, external laryngeal, oesophageal striated muscles, muscles of the soft palate, sternocleidomastoid, and trapezius.

questions.text: Schick test is used to test _______
questions.solution:
Susceptibility of an individual is determined using the Schick test. It is a neutralization based test.

The Schick test is based on the ability of the circulating antitoxin to neutralise the diphtheria toxin given intradermally and indicates immunity or susceptibility to the disease. This test is done in Vivo, and not used in routine clinical practice.

Invitro analysis of circulating antitoxins can be done by either passive hemagglutination or neutralisation in cell culture. Antitoxin levels of more than 0.1 IU/ml is considered an index of protective antibody level.

Toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is determined using Elek's gel precipitation test.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about dermatophytes is true?
questions.solution:
Microsporum infects only skin and hair, not nails.

Dermatophytes include 3 genera:

  • Epidermophyton: It infects only skin and nails (not hair). E. floccosum is the only species in this genus.
  • Trichophyton: It infects skin, hair, and nails. The species falling under this genus are-

    • T. mentagrophytes

    • T. violaceum

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage during the disaster?
questions.solution:
• In triage, green is low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.
  • Red is a high priority or transfer; yellow is medium priority and black is dead or moribund patients.
  • Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention.
  • It is done at the site of the disaster.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

questions.text: The anesthesia resident notices slightly increased blood loss during surgery and decides to administer a crystalloid solution as the transfusion point is not yet reached. Which one of the following solutions, would the resident administer in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, as the resident decides to administer a crystalloid solution he would give plasmalyte to increases the intravascular volume. Plasmalyte is a crystalloid solution which is iso-osmolar (osmolarity 294mosm/L) with plasma. In settings other than massive trauma,  lactated Ringer’s solution or Plasmalyte  can be administered in approximately three to four times the volume of the blood lost, until the transfusion point is reached

Composition of Plasmalyte:

  • Na-140 meq/L
  • Cl- 98 meq/L
  • K- 5 meq/L
  • Mg -3 meq/L
  • Acetate and gluconate

The absence of calcium makes it suitable as a diluent for RBC transfusion. And it has less tendency to promote interstitial edema when compared with normal saline.

The other options given above are colloids.

The colloids are of two types: 

  • Blood-derived- human albumin and plasma protein fractions
  • Semisynthetic- dextran, gelatin, hydroxyethyl starch

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is brought to the hospital in a state of anxiety and agitation. He admits to taking a substance of abuse 1 hour back. He is aware of his surroundings but his attention is fleeting. He doesn't always answer questions. On examination, there was conjunctival injection, dry mouth, and tachycardia. Which among the following is the substance of abuse in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of cannabis intoxication.

Cannabis is a commonly used psychoactive drug. Tetrahydrocannabinol is mainly responsible for the psychoactive effects. The plant is usually cut, dried, and rolled into cigarettes which are smoked. Some names for cannabis are marijuana, grass, pot, weed, and Mary Jane. Individuals who use cannabis every day for weeks to months are likely to become dependent.

Features associated with cannabis intoxication:

  • Conjunctival injection (red eye)
  • Dry mouth
  • Tachycardia
  • Increased appetite
  • Heightens user's sensitivities to external stimuli
  • Depersonalization and derealization
  • Impaired motor skill

Amotivational syndrome has been associated with long-term heavy use of cannabis. It is characterized by a person's unwillingness to persist in a task- at school, at work, or in any setting that requires prolonged attention or tenacity. Persons are described as becoming apathetic and anergic, usually gaining weight, and appearing slothful.

Other options :

Option B: Acute cocaine intoxication presents with delusions of persecution, paranoia, and suspiciousness. The patient also experiences a feeling of insects crawling under the skin, also known as cocaine bugs or formication, which is a characteristic feature of cocaine abuse. It is essential to differentiate acute cocaine intoxication from acute schizophrenia which it closely resembles. 

Option C: The signs of alcohol intoxication are slurred speech, dizziness, incoordination, unsteady gait, nystagmus, impairment in attention or memory, double vision, and stupor or coma. As these features are not pronounced in this patient it is unlikely that the patient is under the influence of alcohol.

Option D - Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a potent hallucinogen where intoxication presents with maladaptive behavioral and perceptual changes and physiological signs such as pupillary dilation, tachycardia, sweating, palpitations, blurring of vision, tremors, and incoordination. The patient in the given scenario does not have any perceptual change as he is aware of his surroundings.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was a known case of alcoholic liver disease came with complaints of fever, abdominal discomfort and distension, and fatigue. On local examination of the abdomen, shifting dullness was present and the fluid thrill test was found to be positive. Which of the following decreases in the above-mentioned condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts worsening of liver disease causing ascites which leads to hypoalbuminemia (decrease in albumin). The history of fever can most likely point toward bacterial peritonitis which is an important complication of end-stage liver disease. 

Acute-phase reactants are plasma proteins whose concentrations increase or decrease in the serum during inflammation. They are synthesized in the liver. The synthesis is mainly stimulated by cytokines like IL-6, IL-1 and TNF. 

Albumin is a negative acute-phase reactant that decreases during an inflammatory process. There is a shift of albumin from the intravascular compartment to the extravascular compartment due to increased oncotic pressure and decreased hydrostatic pressure. 

Other negative acute-phase reactants:

  • Transferrin
  • Retinol-binding protein
  • Antithrombin

Other options:

Options B, C, and D: Fibrinogen, SAA, and CRP are positive acute phase reactants that increase during an inflammatory process.

Other positive acute-phase reactants include:

  • Procalcitonin
  • Ferritin
  • Hepcidin
  • Thrombopoietin

questions.text: A barium meal study of a patient showed the following. What is the most common carcinoma to develop in this condition?
questions.solution:
In this case, the barium meal study shows the bird-beak appearance and the likely diagnosis is achalasia. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common carcinoma to develop in achalasia due to long-standing, retained, undigested fermenting food in the body of the esophagus, causing mucosal irritation.

 Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a timed barium study, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a 'bird's beak' at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: An infant in the neonatal intensive care unit was observed to have a minimal nasal flare, marked xiphoid retractions, intercostal retractions that were just visible, and inspiratory lag with a grunt audible with a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score?
questions.solution:
Silverman-Anderson score of this infant would be 6. 

Silverman Anderson score is more suited for preterms with hyaline membrane disease. This score is indicative of the severity of respiratory distress. It is given as follows:

Score 0 1 2
Upper chest retraction (Chest movement) sync lag on inspiration see-saw
Lower chest retraction (Intercostal retraction) none just visible marked
Xiphoid retraction none just visible marked
Nasal dilatation none minimal marked
Grunt none stethoscope only naked ear


In the given scenario:

  • Presence of grunt audible on stethoscope- 1
  • Minimal nasal flaring- 1
  • Marked xiphoid retraction- 2
  • Intercostal retractions that were just visible- 1
  • Chest movement with inspiratory lag- 1

Total score: 6

A score of >6 indicates impending respiratory failure.

The image given below gives the scoring system for the Silverman-Anderson score.

Another score called the Downes’ Score is more comprehensive and can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Scoring is to be done every half an hour and charting is carried out to monitor progress. The parameters in Downes' scores are:

  • Respiratory rate
  • Air entry
  • Cyanosis
  • Grunting
  • Retraction

Downe’s score of >6 means impending respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the OPD with excessive salivation and wetting of pillows for the past 1 month. She is a known case of schizophrenia and was admitted 1 month back due to her tendencies of self-harm, following which she was started on a new drug. What is the drug responsible for her complaints?
questions.solution:
Clozapine causes wet pillow syndrome. It causes excessive drooling of saliva at night time.

The other side effects include agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and weight gain. Clozapine also has the highest risk of precipitating seizures.

Haloperidol causes the highest extra-pyramidal symptoms, akathisia, and hyperprolactinemia • It can also lead to sedation, weight gain, and hypotension.

Risperidone is known to cause hyperprolactinemia and other metabolic side effects.

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation

 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Clozapine Agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)
Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract

questions.text: The Fernandez reaction of lepromin test is read at _________
questions.solution:
The Fernandez reaction or the early reaction of the lepromin test is read at 48 hours.

Lepromin test is a prognostic test used in the classification of Leprosy. It has no diagnostic purpose.

  • It involves performing an intradermal injection of the lepromin antigen (synthesized from M. leprae) on the flexor surface of the forearm.
  • It is an indicator of cell-mediated immunity and hence may be positive in normal individuals as well. 
  • A positive test indicates good cell-mediated immunity and towards Tuberculoid side of the spectrum
  • A negative test indicates poor cell-mediated immunity and towards the Lepromatous side of the spectrum.

There are two possible responses:

  • The early reaction of Fernandez - Positive within 48-72 hours if there is the erythema measuring >10 mm
  • Late Reaction of Mitsuda - Positive at 21 days if there is the onset of a papule measuring 5 mm or more (A better indicator of Cell-Mediated Immunity)

questions.text: A bone biopsy sample is taken from a patient with suspected bone tumour. PAS staining was done and found to be positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PAS staining is positive in Ewing's sarcoma, as tumour cells are rich in glycogen. However, they stain negatively for reticulin.

The image given below shows PAS staining done in Ewing's sarcoma.

Note: Lymphomas are PAS negative and reticulin positive.

questions.text: Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by ________
questions.solution:
Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by the rubella virus.

The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataracts, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions is referred to as expanded rubella syndrome. The thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term blueberry muffin syndrome. 

While the blueberry muffin syndrome is characteristically caused by rubella, the blueberry muffin-like hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions may also be seen in the case of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

The following image shows blueberry syndrome:

Other options: Maternal varicella occurring close to delivery may cause congenital varicella syndrome in babies in the first 2 weeks of life. This presents as a serious disseminated disease with a risk of encephalitis and pneumonia.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not crossed by the root of the mesentery?
questions.solution:
Right ureter(and not left ureter) is crossed by the root of the mesentery.

  • Abdominal aorta

questions.text: A medical student while examining a patient during his skin postings identifies a flat, circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion of >1 cm size that differs in color from the surrounding skin. The lesion described in the above patient  is a ________________
questions.solution:
A Patch is a flat, circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion of >1 cm that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape.

  • A macule is a lesion of a similar description but of size <1 cm.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with fever and malaise for 4 days. On examination, he has rashes over his back as shown in the image.  The causative agent of this disease remains dormant in ________
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of chickenpox caused by the Varicella-zoster virus, which remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglion.

The image depicts the rash of chickenpox, as different stages of the rash can be seen at one time.

Characteristics of the rash of chickenpox:

  • Superficial
  • Pleomorphic
  • Centripetal
  • Unilocular
  • Symmetrical
  • Spares palms and soles, affects flexor surfaces and axilla
  • Rapid evolution
  • Dewdrop on Rose-petal appearance (shown in the image below)

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles).

questions.text: A microbiologist working on influenza virus in a lab, observes reversal of hemagglutination. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination seen in influenza virus.

Influenza virus contains two surface antigens. Hemagglutinin (HA) causes RBC agglutination and facilitates viral entry into cells. Neuraminidase (NA) acts as an enzyme that destroys the receptor HA uses to bind to RBCs. Thus, it causes elution/reversal of hemagglutination. The virus is released from the red cell surface. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl with bony defects was brought by her mother to the gynecological OPD. She had attained menarche a day before. Physical examination revealed the development of secondary sexual characteristics. Which of the following is wrong about her condition?

choices.text: Cafe au lait lesions with coast of california appearance
May be associated with thyrotoxicosis and cushing's syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical features of precocious puberty and bone defects suggest the diagnosis of Mc Cune-Albright syndrome.

Mc Cune- Albright syndrome have cafe au lait lesions with rough borders(coast of Maine appearance). Cafe au lait lesions with smooth borders(Coast of California) are seen in neurofibromatosis. 

McCune-Albright syndrome is due to activating mutations in the GNAS1 gene, which encodes the alpha subunit of the stimulatory G protein (Gs alpha). This gain of function mutation results in autonomous function in bone, skin, and endocrine glands which are responsible for the wide range of clinical manifestations.

Following are features of the syndrome

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia: most commonly occurs in the maxilla and other craniofacial bones, ribs, femur, or tibia. Expanding bone lesions may cause pain, deformity, fractures, and nerve entrapment.
  • Cafe au lait spots with rough borders
  • Hyperfunctioning of the endocrine system. The most common endocrinopathy is pseudo precocious puberty in girls. Adrenal adenomas and Thyrotoxicosis, acromegaly, hyperparathyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, and pseudo precocious puberty in boys are also seen

questions.text: Blood supply during exercise remains unaltered in __________.
questions.solution:
Cerebral circulation remains relatively unaltered during exercise by autoregulatory mechanisms to ensure a constant supply of oxygen and nutrients to the brain, maintaining stable function despite increased physical activity.

Stable cerebral circulation during exercise helps maintain cognitive functions, such as concentration, coordination, and decision-making, which are essential during physical activity.

In contrast, blood flow is redirected to active muscles and the heart (Option D), where it increases significantly to meet the heightened demand for oxygen and energy. Redirection is necessary to support the increased workload of these tissues. Other regions, such as inactive muscles (Option A) and hepato-splanchnic circulation (Option B), experience reduced blood flow as the body prioritizes areas directly involved in the exercise.

As muscle work output rises, oxygen consumption increases, leading to the dilation of blood vessels in the muscles. This dilation enhances venous return, which in turn boosts cardiac output. In a normal, untrained person, cardiac output can increase by just over four times the resting level. In contrast, a well-trained athlete can boost their cardiac output by about six times. Remarkably, in some marathoners, cardiac outputs as high as 35 to 40 L/min have been recorded, which is seven to eight times the normal resting output.

questions.text: Which among the following is the best diagnostic modality for emphysematous pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
CT is the best diagnostic modality for emphysematous pyelonephritis.

It may show the following diagnostic features:

  • Enlarged, destructed renal parenchyma
  • Small bubbly or linear streaks of gas radiating from the papilla
  • Fluid collections, with gas-fluid levels
  • Focal necrotic areas +/-abscess

Emphysematous pyelonephritis refers to infection of kidneys, with characteristic gas formation within or around the kidneys. If not treated early, it may lead to fulminant sepsis and carries a high mortality. E-coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and proteus mirabilis are typically responsible for this condition.

Note: MRI is reserved only for cases in whom a CT is contraindicated, as the signal-void due to gas may simulate calculi or fluid movement.

questions.text: Which of the following nematodes is oviparous?
questions.solution:
Ancylostoma is oviparous, which means the organisms lay eggs to reproduce.

Female nematodes are classified as follows:

  • Oviparous – Laying eggs
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris, Trichuris
    • Segmented eggs: Ancylostoma, Necator
    • Eggs containing larva: Enterobius
  • Viviparous – Producing larvae
    • E.g., Trichinella, Wuchereria, Brugia, Dracunculus
  • Ovoviviparous – laying eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.
    • E.g., Strongyloides

Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) larvae enter the human host by skin penetration and undergo extraintestinal migration through the venous circulation to the lungs. They enter the alveoli, climb up to the bronchial tree and pharynx, and are swallowed. The larvae reach the small intestine and become adult worms.

Clinical manifestations include vitamin B12 deficiency and iron deficiency anemia, resulting from chronic occult intestinal blood loss. Dermatitis referred to as ground itch may occur when they penetrate human skin. Eosinophilic pneumonia can also be seen. The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with A. duodenale.

Oval, segmented hookworm eggs can be demonstrated in the feces by direct wet microscopy or concentration method. Stool culture by the Harada-Mori method demonstrates third-stage filariform larvae.

Infection with a zoonotic hookworm, especially Ancylostoma braziliense, can result in the subcutaneous migration of the larvae, causing cutaneous larva migrans.

The image given below shows cutaneous larva migrans.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?
questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone acts through aquaporin channel 2.

ADH binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.

Clinical note: Lithium, which is often used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments can you use to measure corneal thickness?
questions.solution:
The pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness.

Options A and D: A keratometer (ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center.

Option C: Specular microscopy is the study of the corneal endothelium under a very high magnification (100 times greater than slit lamp biomicroscopy). Endothelium can be analyzed for cellular size, shape, density, and distribution. The healthy endothelial cell is a regular hexagon, and the normal cell density in a young adult is about 3000 cells/mm2.

questions.text:
A studious intern who is posted in the medicine ward found a significant decrease in the platelet count after the administration of certain drugs. This Drug-induced thrombocytopenia is common following the administration of ________
1. Heparin 
2. Vancomycin
3. Quinine
questions.solution:
All the three given drugs heparin, vancomycin, and quinine can cause thrombocytopenia.

Drugs can cause thrombocytopenia through direct effects on platelets or secondary to immunologically mediated platelet destructions. The drugs most commonly implicated are quinine, quinidine, and vancomycin, all of which bind platelet glycoprotein and create antigenic determinants that are recognized by antibodies.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came to a dermatology clinic with the complaints of brittle scalp hair and the presence of firmly adherent, soft, white nodules along the hair shaft as given in the image below. Pruritus is absent. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of brittle scalp hair and firmly adherent, yellow soft nodules along the hair shaft is suggestive of white piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Trichosporon beigelii.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • Black piedra: It is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.
  • White piedra: It is characterized by the presence of soft, white, or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.

Management:

Shaving or cutting off the affected hair along with topical antifungals.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the hospital complaining of severe epigastric pain which used to get aggravated after having food. Upper GI endoscopy shows ulcers in gastric body and duodenum. What type of ulcer is this according to modified Johnson classification for a gastric ulcer?

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?
  1. Orphan drugs are drugs that are not used anymore.
  2. Orphan drugs are drugs for rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies.
  3. Orphan drugs act on orphan receptors.
  4. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified.
  5. Orphan receptors are receptors that do not serve any purpose.
questions.solution:
Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified.

There are two types of drug development. They are:

  • Traditional drug development: Initial drug discovery is followed by the characterization of the receptors the drugs are used to act on.
  • Contemporary drug development: Due to advances in molecular biology and genome sequencing, receptors are identified initially. These receptors do not have an endogenous mediator or ligand and are thus known as orphan receptors. However, they are potential targets for the development of new drugs, which can later be identified using chemical screening. 

Orphan drugs are drugs used for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases. Special incentives are given by the government to pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs. Examples of orphan drugs are:

  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Digoxin antibody (Digibind)
  • Fomepizole

questions.text: Most common extra-renal manifestation seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is?
questions.solution:
Most common extra-renal manifestation seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is heptic cysts.

Most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Pancreatic and splenic cysts are less frequent.

Cysts can be found in the arachnoid membrane and they do not cause symptoms, but may increase the risk of developing a subdural hematoma.

Extrarenal cysts in ADPKD:

  • Hepatic cysts
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Seminal vesicle cysts
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts

In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease(ADPKD), cysts are least likely to be present in the lungs.

Note: Polycystic liver disease associated with ADPKD is different from autosomal dominant polycystic liver disease(ADPLD) which does not progress to renal failure.

There is a 3 fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.

  • Sporadic in origin

questions.text: A known case of tubotympanic disease was taken up for surgery and on examining the middle ear, few chalky white deposits were found between the ossicles. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Candidal infection of the middle ear

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tympanosclerosis. It is a sequela of long-standing middle ear disease where there are hyaline deposits within the middle ear, which calcify leading to impaired mobility of ossicles.

The common sites are the tympanic membrane, promontory, ossicles, joints, tendons, and oval and round windows.

When hyalinization and calcification involve only the tympanic membrane, it is known as myringosclerosis.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding estrogen?
questions.solution:
Estrogen causes an increase in apolipoprotein levels.

Estrogen increases plasma HDL and triglyceride levels. It also causes an increased turnover of LDL receptors.

questions.solution:
The pelvis along with the skull gives almost 98% accurate information in sex determination.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type II (Pompe's disease) glycogen storage disease is the most probable diagnosis from the above-given clinical scenario.

The clinical symptoms are hypotonia (floppy infant), hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, which is characteristically seen in Pompe's disease. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major criterion for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in the low-risk population?
questions.solution:

questions.text: The following is the histopathological image of the anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid. The cells are termed term anaplastic because of ___________

choices.text: Replacement of one type of cell by other
Variation in cell size and shape

questions.solution:
Anaplasia refers to a lack of differentiation.

The extent to which neoplastic cells resemble normal cells, both morphologically and functionally, is called differentiation.

Malignant neoplasms that are composed of poorly differentiated cells are said to be anaplastic. Hence, anaplasia is considered the hallmark of malignant transformation.

Other morphological features of malignancy:

  • Pleomorphism: Variation in the size and shape of the cells
  • Increased N:C ratio: The nuclei are disproportionately large for the cell. In normal cells, the nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4, whereas it becomes 1:1 in malignant cells.
  • Hyperchromasia: Coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei.
  • Increased mitosis: Atypical, bizarre mitotic figures, sometimes with tripolar, quadripolar, or multipolar spindles
  • Loss of polarity: Sheets or large masses of tumor cells grow in an anarchic, disorganized fashion.

The term anaplasia means to form backward implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely about 'supposititious child'?

choices.text: The child is delivered after death of biological father
The child  born to another mother
The child dead after 1 month of delivery
The child is abandoned by the parents

questions.solution:
The child born to another mother is most likely about supposititious children.

Supposititious child means fictitious child. Women pretend to be pregnant and later produce a child born to another mother as her own. Or she may substitute a male child for a female child born of her, or for an abortion.

Mostly the objectives behind this are to obtain money or claim a property. Other legal issues involve blackmailing a man or bringing a charge of separation against a man.

In the above case, the woman should be examined for signs of pregnancy and delivery. The medical evidence can be used when the age of the supposititious child does not correspond to the date of the pretended delivery. DNA fingerprinting will be conclusive.

A posthumous child is a child born alive after the death of his or her father who was conceived prior to the death of the father.

questions.text: A patient who has been on chemotherapy for 3 days has laboratory findings showing hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following malignancies is the least likely?
questions.solution:
This patient being on chemotherapy for 3 days and labs showing hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia indicate the patient has tumor lysis syndrome, which is rare with solid tumors. hence, the least likely malignancy, in this case, is renal cell carcinoma. 

TLS is most often associated with the treatment of Burkitt’s lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and other rapidly proliferating lymphomas, but it also may be seen with chronic leukemias and, rarely, with solid tumors.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was administered succinylcholine as a muscle relaxant prior to his surgery. Which one of the following effects cannot be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine produces hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia. The use of succinylcholine increases the plasma K+ levels by 0.5 mEq/L. This increase in K+ is well tolerated by healthy individuals but could be deleterious in patients with severe metabolic acidosis and hypovolemia.

Low doses of succinylcholine can produce negative chronotropic and inotropic effects resulting in bradycardia, but higher doses usually increase heart rate and contractility and elevate circulating catecholamine levels. Children are particularly susceptible to profound bradycardia following the administration of succinylcholine.

Intracranial pressure and Intragastric pressure will be increased with Sch.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. HIV-antibody spot test was negative, however p24 antigen assay was positive. You explain to him that he is currently in the window period for HIV. Which of the following statements would you use to explain the concept to him?

choices.text: It is the time period between infection and onset of first symptoms
It is the time period between infection and detection of antibodies
It is the time period between exposure and onset of viral multiplication
It is the time period between exposure and appearance of symptoms

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has experienced a high-risk exposure to HIV due to sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. 

The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period.

The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and PCR.

questions.text: Breathing systems use soda lime to absorb expired carbon dioxide during anesthesia. When the carbon dioxide absorption capacity of soda lime is exhausted, it changes color from white to purple. Which of the following is likely to have been used as an indicator in this soda-lime?
questions.solution:
As the color of soda-lime changes from white to purple, the indicator used is likely to be ethyl violet.

Breathing systems function by delivering oxygen and anesthetic gases to the patient and removing carbon dioxide. This can be done by washout with adequate gas flow or by using carbon dioxide absorbant media like soda lime. 

Ethyl violet has a critical pH of 10.3. It is added to soda-lime to assess the integrity of the absorbent. As CO2 is absorbed, the pH reduces below 10.3 resulting in the purple color, indicating that the absorptive capacity of the material has been consumed.

Phenolphthalein White Pink
Mimosa 2 Red White
Clayton yellow Red Yellow
Ethyl orange Orange Yellow

The pH indicator changes color as a result of increasing hydrogen ion concentration and absorbent exhaustion. The absorbent should be replaced when 50-70% of color has been changed. If rested exhausted granules may revert to their original color but, no significant recovery of absorptive capacity occurs.

questions.text: An epidemiologist wants to identify missing cases of HIV-positive individuals in the community, that were not on the notified cases list. This process is known as?
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases that are not on the notified cases list.

Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases, in addition to the already existing new and old cases. It is used for supplementing routine notifications. The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

Monitoring is the analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status or environment of a population.

Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health.

Evaluation compares results with the intended objectives, or more simply assesses how well a program is performing.

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: What is the last visual field to be affected in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The temporal visual field is the last field to be affected in glaucoma.

The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and finally, the nasal fibers.

Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma. 

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: What percentage of children are expected to manifest cystic fibrosis if the father and mother, both are carriers for the disease?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the disease is likely to be manifested in 25% of children. 

If parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes):

  • 25% of the children have normal genotype
  • 50% are carriers
  • 25% are homozygous and hence the disease is manifested

In autosomal recessive disorders, the disease manifests itself when the offspring has a homozygous state. Multiple affected members are seen in the same generation. Other generations are not affected. The following pedigree chart depicts an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

Cystic fibrosis results due to a defective mutation in the gene encoding for cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR gene). It plays an important role in mucociliary transport along the respiratory mucosa. It also helps regulate the amount of exocrine gland secretion.

The defect in the ion channel results in the production of hyper viscous, adherent secretions which can obstruct the airways. Organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus can grow in the sputum. The exocrine pancreas can undergo fibrotic scarring, cyst formation, and acinar tissue loss. The viscid secretions can lead to pancreatic duct obstruction. The flow of digestive enzymes to the duodenum is hence impaired.

Symptoms include sinusitis, steatorrhea, and abdominal pain. Distal intestinal obstruction is a complication due to difficulty in excreting intestinal contents. In neonates, it can present as meconium ileus. 

Detection of high levels of trypsinogen is used in newborn screening. Chloride levels >60mEq/L in the sweat of affected patients are diagnostic. Hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis and hypokalemia may also be seen.

Postural drainage, short-term antibiotics, and inhaled bronchodilators can be used for medical management. The definitive treatment is lung transplantation.

questions.text: A woman comes to the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, the discharge was profuse and had a fishy odour. Which of the following is the best criteria to confirm the diagnosis?

questions.text: Which stage of ROP  is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Image shows intraretinal ridge formation and it corresponds to stage 2 of ROP.

  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), previously known as retrolental fibroplasia, is a disease of the eye that affects prematurely born babies.
  • ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases. As such, all premature babies are at risk for ROP, and very low birth weight is an additional risk factor.
  • Both oxygen toxicity and relative hypoxia can contribute to the development of ROP.
  • Location
    Concentric zones centered on the optic disc are described.
    • Zone I is bounded by an imaginary circle, the radius of which is twice the distance from the disc to the center of the macula. 
    • Zone II extends concentrically from the edge of zone I; its radius extends from the center of the disc to the nasal ora serrata.
    • Zone III consists of a residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II
  • Stages of ROP:
    • Stage 1: Demarcation line
    • Stage 2: Intraretinal ridge formation
    • Stage 3: Neovascularization
    • Stage 4: Subtotal retinal detachment
    • Stage 5: Total retinal detachment
  • "Plus" disease signifies a tendency to progression and is characterized by the dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels involving at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. 
  • Aggressive posterior ("rush" disease, AP-ROP) is uncommon but if untreated usually progresses to stage 5, sometimes within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease, and ill-defined nature of the retinopathy.
  • Screening
    • First ROP screening should be done at 4 weeks if the gestational age is 28–34 weeks or birth weight is <2000 g.
    • First ROP screening should be done at 3 weeks if gestational age is <28 weeks or birth weight is <1200 g.
  • Treatment
    • Type 1. Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours for type 1 disease. It is done by laser photocoagulation of peripheral avascular retina.
    • Type 2 disease requires observation for progression.
    • Intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) agents, e.g., bevacizumab (only for AP-ROP)
    • Laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina
    • Pars plana vitrectomy for tractional retinal detachment not involving the macula (stage 4A)

  • Type 1 ROP
    1) Zone I ROP with plus disease
    2) Zone I, no plus, stage 3 ROP
    3) Zone II with plus, stage 2 or 3 ROP

Note: Non-type 1 ROP is labelled type 2 ROP

questions.text: A 73 years old patient with a history of chronic congestive cardiac failure and secondary pulmonary hypertension was admitted in the ICU for severe breathlessness and pedal edema. The patient dies on the 2nd day of admission and an autopsy was done. On examination of abdominal viscera the liver was found to be enlarged with the following appearance on the cross-section of the specimen. False about this condition is:

choices.text: The pathology here is cirrhosis of liver
Diagnosis is based on Clinical evaluation

questions.solution:
This is an image of a "nutmeg" liver seen with chronic passive congestion of the liver. Note the dark red congested regions that represent the accumulation of RBC's in centrilobular regions.

Congestive hepatopathy is diffuse venous congestion within the liver that results from right-sided heart failure (usually due to cardiomyopathy, tricuspid regurgitation, mitral insufficiency, cor pulmonale, or constrictive pericarditis).

Pathogenesis:

  • Moderate or severe right-sided heart failure causes raised central venous pressure, which is transmitted to the liver via the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins.
  • Chronic congestion leads to atrophy of hepatocytes, distention of sinusoids, and centri zonal fibrosis, which, if severe, progresses to cirrhosis (cardiac cirrhosis).
  • The basis for liver cell death is probably sinusoidal thrombosis that propagates to the central veins and branches of the portal vein, causing ischemia.

Clinical Picture:

  • Most patients are asymptomatic.
  • However, moderate congestion causes right upper quadrant discomfort (due to stretching of the liver capsule) and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Ascites may result from the transmitted central venous hypertension; infrequently, splenomegaly results.
  • With transmitted central venous hypertension, the hepatojugular reflex is present, unlike in hepatic congestion due to Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on Clinical evaluation
  • Congestive hepatopathy is suspected in patients who have right-sided heart failure, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Laboratory test results are modestly abnormal: unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin < 3 mg/dL), elevated (usually < 2- to 3-fold) aminotransferases, and prolonged PT/INR.
  • Ascitic fluid, if present, has a high albumin content (typically > 2.5 g/dL); in contrast, only 10% of patients with cirrhotic ascites have ascitic albumin levels that high.
  • Because the laboratory abnormalities are nonspecific, recognition of congestive hepatopathy is ultimately clinical.

questions.text: One of the most important functions of the hypothalamus is to link the nervous system to the endocrine system via the pituitary gland. Which of the part of the hypothalamus is correctly matched with its function among the given options?
questions.solution:
In the hypothalamus, the suprachiasmatic nucleus functions as the principal pacemaker for circadian rhythms. The pacemaker receives input from the eyes and many other parts of the nervous system, and these inputs mediate the effects exerted by the external environment (retinohypothalamic tract).

Other options:

Option A: The anterior hypothalamus activates mechanisms to cool the body in response to heat via the reflex response. Stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus causes cutaneous vasodilation and sweating, thereby cooling the body. Lesions in this region cause hyperthermia, with rectal temperatures sometimes reaching 43°C (109.4°F).

Option C: Hunger centre is present in the lateral hypothalamus which is responsible for eating behavior.

Option D: Synthesis of oxytocin takes place in the supraoptic and paraventricular nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Lower incidence of incisional hernias as compared to vertical incisions
Location is 3 cm above the pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected. The rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in cesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Compared to vertical incisions, the Pfannenstiel incision offers superior cosmesis and lower incisional hernia rates.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transvere and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse incisions:

Advantages-

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Disadvantages-

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

Vertical incisions:

Advantages-

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages-

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: A curious medical student wants to study injured cells in a light microscope. What is the most important light microscopic feature he would notice in this type of cell injury?

choices.text: Nuclear changes like Pyknosis and Karyolysis

questions.solution:
Nuclear changes like pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis are the features of irreversible cell injury that are visible on light microscopy.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with nutritional melalgia?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid/ Vitamin B5 deficiency leads to burning feet syndrome, also known as nutritional melalgia or Gopalan's syndrome.

It acts as a functional part of CoA or acyl carrier protein. CoA plays a role in fatty acid oxidation, the citric acid cycle, acetylations, and cholesterol synthesis. ACP is involved in the fatty acid synthesis.

Deficiency leads to peripheral nerve damage leading to burning foot syndrome. It is mostly seen during a famine, in prison camps, in chronic alcoholics, and in renal dialysis patients.

questions.text: In a patient with an acoustic neuroma involving the sensory division of the facial nerve, the Hitzelberger sign was positive. What is the other name for this nerve?
questions.solution:
The sensory division of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg. The facial nerve is a mixed nerve having the motor and a sensory root.

Hitzelberger sign refers to hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in acoustic neuroma due to the compression of the facial nerve.

Option A: Jacobson’s nerve - the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve). It is associated with glomus tympanicum.
