Option D: Herring’s nerve - the carotid sinus branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve).

questions.text: A 50-year old patient presented with scaly plaques, well-demarcated from unaffected skin, with sharply delineated edges as shown in the image given below. The lesions showed an isomorphic response and the Auspitz sign was positive. Which of the following types is the most common variant of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriasis, with the image showing well-demarcated scaly plaques surrounded by Woronoff's rings. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis.

Plaque/Discoid psoriasis, also known as psoriasis vulgaris accounts for almost 90% of all psoriasis cases. It presents as a papulosquamous rash, with reddish edematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, which are well-demarcated from unaffected skin with sharply delineated edges. Plaques may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the halo or ring of Woronoff. The scalp is one of the most common and first affected areas in plaque psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash

It is linked to infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which cause proliferation of keratinocytes. This leads to the formation of thick plaques, epidermal hyperplasia, and parakeratosis. 

It can occur in sites of cutaneous trauma and old scarring, termed as Koebner's phenomenon. It is suggested that trauma stimulates immune activation. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients.

The image below shows Koebner's phenomenon seen in plaque psoriasis.

Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  1. Beta-blockers
  2. Synthetic antimalarials
  3. NSAIDS
  4. Lithium
  5. ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  6. Interferon alpha
  7. Tetracycline
  8. Terbinafine
  9. Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

Lesions can be described as:

  • Red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • Encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • Appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

  • Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.)
  • Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities
  • Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized and exanthemic variants are described
  • Scalp psoriasis: well demarcated plaques on the retroauricular areas and posterior upper neck
  • Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent
  • Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns
  • Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches and leukonychia are common on the nail plate

  • Signs:

    • Koebner phenomenon: new psoriatic papules at sites of skin trauma
    • Auspitz sign: pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed

Woronoff ring: an area of blanching surrounding resolving psoriatic plaques

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showing focal foveal detachment.

There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site of oedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment.

Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluid accumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as central serous choriopathy (CSC).

If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patients also have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, a circular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen.

Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids are contraindicated.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy had recurrent episodes of bacterial infection. There is also a history of bloody diarrhoea and eczema during the first month of life. Peripheral smear showed abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia and small-sized platelets. Patients often present in infancy with bruising, bloody diarrhea, eczema, and susceptibility to recurrent infections. It occurs due to mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

Along with microthrombocytopenia, peripheral smear shows loss of T lymphocytes. Patients are also unable to produce antibodies to antigens, thereby making them immunocompromised. As a result, there is also an increased risk of autoimmune disorders and cancers like B-cell lymphomas.

Splenectomy improves platelet counts in these patients since increased platelet destruction in the spleen is prevented. However, the only definitive treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition due to a defect in IIb/IIIa leading to defective platelet aggregation.

Option B: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a condition characterized by low platelet count due to autoantibody-mediated destruction. Patients present with easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and bleeding into the skin and soft tissues. Laboratory findings typically show isolated thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition occurring due to defective adhesion of platelets to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. It is due to a deficiency of the glycoprotein complex Ib–IX on the platelet membrane. Patients often present with bleeding tendencies.

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the incision being depicted in the image?

choices.text: Done to facilitate the delivery of aftercoming head
Incision is done at 2 o' clock and 10 o' clock positions

questions.solution:
The image depicts Duhrssen’s incision, not episiotomy.

  • Can be made at 2 and 10 O’ clock position on the cervix.
  • An additional incision at 6 o’clock position is sometimes needed.
  • Done for delivery of aftercoming head in breech or delivery of head through an incompletely dilated cervix.
  • There is a significant risk of haemorrhage; the cervical incision may extend upwards within the broad ligament causing broad ligament haematoma.

An episiotomy, on the other hand, begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline, which yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline. The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child developed fever during an epidemic of influenza. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this child?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is contraindicated in this child due to the risk of development of Reye syndrome.

Children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever have a risk of developing Reye's syndrome on administration of aspirin or other salicylates.

Features of Reye syndrome include:

  • Acute onset of encephalopathy
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Fatty infiltration of the liver 

Option A - Acetaminophen is considered the antipyretic of choice in children with viral infections.

Options C and D - Oseltamivir and baloxavir are antiviral drugs used in influenza.

questions.text: A 13-year old boy with 70 kg weight and hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. Which of the following signs will be positive?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in the above case is slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE). Trethowan's sign is seen in SCFE.

Points in favor of SCFE:

  • 13-year old child: As SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, commonly during 11-20 years, due to the weakening of upper femoral physis. Most common age of presentation of Perthe's disease is 4-8 years.
  • Obesity and hypothyroidism: Obesity, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, hyperparathyroidism, growth hormone excess, Turner's syndrome, Klinefelter's syndrome, and chronic renal failure are all important associations of SCFE.
  • Limitation of abduction and internal rotation
  • Tenderness in scarpa's triangle

Trethowan's sign is seen in SCFE. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign.

Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.

 

Other options:

Siffert Katz sign: In Blount's disease, the knee is stable in full extension, but the medial femoral condyle may sublux posteromedially (into the depressed medial tibial plateau) at 10-20 degrees of flexion. This is called Siffert-katz sign.

The increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate has been named the Terry Thomas sign after the gap-toothed smile. A scapholunate gap of >3 mm is suggestive of instability, with a gap >5 mm diagnostic of SLD if there is a positive cortical ring sign.

Spur sign: Seen in transverse fracture of acetabulum.
